filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive www.blakearchive.org is pleased to announce the publication of new electronic editions of The Marriage of Heaven and Hell Copy G and Visions of the Daughters of Albion Copy P, both printed c. 1818. This is the first reproduction of Marriage Copy G and the first full color reproduction of Visions Copy P since the badly-degraded filmstrips produced by Micro Methods Ltd. in the 1970s.
The Marriage of Heaven and Hell Copy G is in the Houghton Library, Harvard University, and Visions of the Daughters of Albion Copy P is in the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. They join copies of Marriage and Visions from other printings: Marriage Copies C (1790), H (1790/1821), F (1794), D (1795), and I (1827), and Visions Copies C and J (1793), F (1794), and G (1795). Other copies of Marriage and Visions are forthcoming: Marriage Copy K (Plates 21-24) and Copies L and M (Plates 25-27), from the first printing of the plates in 1790, with Plates 24 and 25 in first states; and Visions Copy O, printed with Copy P.
The electronic editions have newly edited SGML-encoded texts and new images scanned and color-corrected from first-generation 4x5" transparencies; text and images are each fully searchable and supported by the Inote and ImageSizer applications described in our previous updates. With the Archive's recently added comparison feature, users can easily juxtapose multiple impressions of any plate across the different copies of an illuminated book.
With the publication of these two titles, the Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of 45 copies of 18 of Blake's 19 illuminated books in the context of full bibliographic information about each work, careful diplomatic transcriptions of all texts, detailed descriptions of all images, and extensive bibliographies. They also join our searchable SGML-encoded electronic edition of David V. Erdman's Complete Poetry and Prose of William Blake. With the forthcoming publication of Jerusalem Copy E, the Archive will contain at least one copy of each of Blake's works in illuminated printing and multiple copies of most.
Marriage Copy G, one of nine extant copies, is the only copy with a variant plate order (1-11, 15, 14, 12, 13, 16-27) that can be traced directly to Blake, and it is the first of his last two copies in which the cave and rock forms on Plates 10, 11, 15, and 20 were printed. These forms were part of the original designs as executed on the plates but were wiped of ink in all earlier copies and thus did not print; they show up only in this copy and Copy I.
The early histories of Marriage Copy G and Visions Copy P are not known, but they were bound together (with The Book of Thel Copy N) until 1890. They also share the same printing session and printing and coloring styles. Both are printed in red-orange ink on one side of RUSE & TURNERS/1815 paper and finished in watercolors and pen and ink. Each impression is numbered in the top right corner and bordered by one thin line drawn in red-orange ink a little over a centimeter around the image, setting off each page like a miniature painting. These extraordinarily beautiful copies were produced in the same session with other books in the Archive: The Book of Thel Copy O and The Book of Urizen Copy G. This late style, which Blake also used c. 1821-22 and 1825-27, can be seen in other books in the Archive: America a Prophecy Copy O and Europe a Prophecy Copy K, published earlier this year, Songs of Innocence and of Experience Copies Z and AA, and The Marriage of Heaven and Hell Copy I.
The editors of the Archive recently photographed over 1250 works by Blake in the British Museum, Department of Prints and Drawings, including all 537 water colors illustrating Edward Young's Night Thoughts and hundreds of pencil sketches (nine newly discovered), drawings, and watercolors. Over the next few years, we will be adding this extensive collection of books, prints, and drawings to the Archive. Many of these works will be reproduced in color for the first time.

provenance.name: Houghton Library, Harvard University
provenance.note: Sold in the same binding with *The Book of Thel* Copy N and *Visions of the Daughters of Albion* Copy P, Sotheby's, 17 Feb. 1890, lot 301 (£121 to the dealer Robson & Kerslake); *The Marriage of Heaven and Hell* Copy G, bound separately, sold by Robson & Kerslake to Alexander Mackay, March 1890; sold by Mackay's widow, Christie's, 26 April 1921, lot 3 (£460 to the dealer Shoebridge); acquired 1922 by Amy Lowell through the dealer Gabriel Wells; bequeathed in 1925 by Lowell to Harvard University.

repository.department: Department of Printing and Graphic Arts

desc.objtitle: THE MARRIAGE of HEAVEN and HELL, Object 1 (Bentley 1, Erdman 1, Keynes 1)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The bottom two-thirds of the plate seems to be beneath the ground level of the natural world, which occupies the top one-third. Near the bottom of the plate, beneath the word "hell" (line 7), a nude couple, perhaps (though not distinctly) female (left) and male (right), kiss while embracing. They are probably intended to represent the "marriage" of "heaven" and "hell" (lines 3, 5, 7). The figure on the right, facing left with body twisted forward, is stretched out horizontally on a cloud; the figure on the left, facing right but with the body seen from behind, hovers above a burst of flames. Above them several other figures, including embracing couples, fly upward between the flames on the left and the clouds (of smoke?) on the right. Above them in turn, at ground level, in a landscape of leafless arching trees whose roots are visible below ground, as if seen in cross-section, a couple strolls on the left and a single figure kneels beside another figure lying on the ground. Birds fly in the sky at the top of the plate. The coloring of the sky on the right hints at a sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: At the ground level of what may be heaven or the natural world, trees, several on each side with one in the center, arch overhead, involving the words "marriage of" (lines 3-4) in the title. Only the tree second from the right bears any suggestion of leaves. The roots of the trees left and right are visible below ground, as if seen in cross-section.
The coloring of the sky on the right hints at a sunrise or sunset.
Several birds, perhaps seven or eight altogether, fly in the sky at the top of the plate.
At ground level on the left, two figures of uncertain gender walk together. The figure on the right, who may be gowned, has his or her left arm is raised at 45 degrees.
At ground level on the right, a figure, probably male and nude or wearing tights, kneels, arms bent upward to his face, perhaps in prayer or grief, and facing another figure lying on the ground.
At ground level on the right, a figure lies on his or her left side on the ground, legs drawn up and possibly arms wrapped around the body. The figure's head probably faces down or forward.

A group of perhaps seventeen or eighteen nude figures, including four embracing couples, fly diagonally upward to the right, toward ground level. One figure in the couple right of "and" (line 6) in the text holds the hand of a small figure, perhaps a child. Above that group of three is another embracing couple; one of these figures has its arms raised at 135 degrees, as do several others in the surrounding areas. Above and to the right of "and" is a group of three or four very small figures, perhaps children.
Flames, representing hell, burst from the lower left side of the plate and extend diagonally almost to the right margin. Thin lines of smoke drift upward from the tips of the flames.
Clouds, possibly of smoke, billow from the lower right side of the plate, representing heaven.

The last letter of "MARRIAGE" (line 3) in the text grows into a vine with at least one loop. It is intertwined with the trees to the right. The penultimate letter grows into two vines, the lower perhaps bearing a leaf, the upper one a loop. Other letters also sprout loopy vines.
The last letter of "and" (line 6) in the text grows into a vine circling around the word.

Near the bottom of the plate, beneath the word "hell" (line 7), a nude couple kiss while embracing. The figure on the left, possibly female and facing right but with her body seen from behind, lies horizontally in a burst of flames. She probably represents "hell" in the "marriage" (line 3) and is in that sense a devil.

Near the bottom of the plate, beneath the word "hell" (line 7), a nude couple kiss while embracing. The figure on the right, indeterminately male or female, lies horizontally on a cloud (of smoke?)—facing to the left, but with the body facing forward. He or she probably represents "heaven" (line 5) in the "marriage" (line 3) and is in that sense an angel.

lg.l: Marriage of

component.illusobjdesc: The words "marriage of" (lines 3-4) in the title are written in a fancy decorative script that blends with the tree branches.

The central area outlined by fire, clouds, and trees may suggest a human head and face. In that case, the arching branches suggest top of head and hair, while the fire and clouds meet in a triangular configuration that suggests a jawline. The lightly-tinted area behind the figures at ground level suggests eye cavities while the central tree trunk hints at a nose.

lg.l: THE
MARRIAGE
of
HEAVEN
and
HELL

illustration.illusobjdesc: At top right a female figure in a long swirling gown holds with her left hand to the upper branch of a leafy tree that extends the length of the right margin. With her right hand she seems to hand something, perhaps fruit, down to a second female figure, similarly gowned, who stands alongside the tree. With her legs crossed, she reaches upward with her right arm while supporting herself with her raised left arm around the trunk. At lower left a male (left) and possibly a female (right), both nude, lie on leafy vegetation. The figure to the left rests his head on his right hand and has its legs crossed. The female to the right lies with arm outstretched and bent at the elbow. Behind the right figure is the head and upper body of a third figure. Between the two groups of figures is a loopy vine with a few leaves. The colors of the sky suggest sunrise or sunset on the left. The scene may represent the "paths of ease" mentioned in the Argument (line 16).

component.illusobjdesc: At top right a female figure in a long swirling gown holds with her left hand to the upper branch of a leafy tree that extends the length of the right margin. Her legs are spread apart and she faces down. Her hair is short and curly. With her right hand she seems to hand something indiscernible down to a second female figure, similarly gowned, who stands alongside the tree.

At bottom right a long-haired female figure in a gown stands alongside the tree. With her legs crossed, and supporting herself with her raised left arm holding the tree trunk, she reaches upward with her right arm as if to take something being offered by the figure in the tree above. Her hair is long and curly.
At lower left two figures, both nude, lie supine on leafy vegetation. The figure on the left, probably male, rests his head on his hand. The figure's legs are crossed.

At lower left two figures, both nude, lie supine on leafy vegetation. The figure on the right, probably female, lies with arm outstretched and bent at the elbow. Her head appears to be facing away from the viewer. Her hair may be drawn back into a bun.
A leafy tree extends the length of the right margin.
Between the two groups of figures is a loopy vine with a few leaves. One branch, just about "fires in the" (line 23) suggests a spiral.
A large leaf appears behind the figure lower left, and a vine(?) grows left of the leaf, attached to the "y" of "Hungry" in (line 25).
The coloring of the ground suggests grass.
The coloring of the sky suggests sunrise or sunset lower left.
In the group of figures at lower left, there seems to be the head and upper body of a third figure adjacent to the head of the figure on the right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the upper left-hand corner of the plate, a bifurcated branch with leaves, perhaps a detachment from the tree in the right margin, curves above "Rintrah" in line 3 and reaches toward the "The" of "The Argument" (line 2). On the bottom half of the plate, five birds with extended wings circumscribe the penultimate stanza.

component.illusobjdesc: In the upper left-hand corner of the plate, a bifurcated branch with leaves, perhaps a detachment from the tree in the right margin, curves above "Rintrah" in line 3 and reaches toward the "The" of "The Argument" (line 2).

On the bottom half of the plate, five birds with extended wings circumscribe the penultimate stanza. One of the birds to the far right of line 22 has a visible crest and a forked tail. Its mouth is open, perhaps in song.

lg.l: Rintrah roars & shakes his fires in the burdend air;
Hungry clouds swag on the deep
Once meek, and in a perilous path,
The just man kept his course along
The vale of death.
Roses are planted where thorns grow,
And on the barren heath
Sing the honey bees.
Then the perilous path was planted:
And a river, and a spring
On every cliff and tomb;
And on the bleached bones
Red clay brought forth.
Till the villain left the paths of ease,
To walk in perilous paths, and drive
The just man into barren climes.
Now the sneaking serpent walks
In mild humility.
And the just man rages in the wilds
Where lions roam.
Rintrah roars & shakes his fires in the
burdend air;
Hungry clouds swag on the deep.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An apparently nude female with long hair that streams behind her head lies horizontal in a burst of flames. Her arms are stretched out just above the horizontal, and her right leg is drawn up.

component.illusobjdesc: An apparently nude female with long hair that streams backward lies supine in a burst of flames. Her arms are raised just above the horizontal, her right leg is drawn up, and her left foot is exposed. She faces left and her palms are facing up.
A nude female lies in a burst of flames.
Blue tinting suggests sky upper right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: To the left a nude female lying supine on a cloud gives birth to a baby that emerges from her vagina. To the right one nude figure lies on a cloud while a second nude figure, male, with short and curly hair, runs past, arms and legs outstretched, and perhaps kisses the first figure. The general positions of the three figures reflect those of the figures on the previous plate, lower left.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude female lying supine on a cloud gives birth to a baby that emerges from between her legs. Her right arm is raised vertically above her head and her fully outstretched right leg and foot are visible.
A nude female lying supine on a cloud gives birth to a baby that emerges with outstretched arms from between her legs. We see only the infant's head and arms, raised at 135 degrees.

One nude figure lies supine on a cloud or stone while a second nude figure, male, with short and curly hair, runs toward the right with arms and legs outstretched. He perhaps kisses the first figure as he runs past, left foot first. He faces away from the viewer.

A nude figure, facing forward, lies supine on a cloud, arms raised horizontally, legs to the left and crossed with left foot forward (right foot forward in most copies). Another figure runs past, perhaps kissing the first.
The background is filled with clouds, with either a dark cloud or a hill or mountain between two groups of figures.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several interlinear ornaments appear above line 2: a feather or leaf curves over the words "heaven is begun," and two vine-like streamers, the second of which contains a single loop, extend from the ascenders of "and" and "thirty." Resembling on a smaller scale the fire-engulfed female of the major design above the text, a small figure, possibly a gowned female, hovers above the second and third words of the line, her arms and body horizontal. Further down—line 7—the figure's male(?) counterpart appears above "Adam." Between lines 2 and 3, a bird with extended wings flies above "three." Another vine-like streamer, interrupted by the "i" of "since," decorates the space between lines 2 and 3; line 8 begins, and the final word of line 9 terminates, with further instances of this motif. Below it, two figures, possibly a male and gowned female, stand facing each other and holding hands on a vine-like arabesque. The background tinting suggests sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Background tinting in the text area suggests sky, perhaps as an extension of the design below the text.

Several vine-like streamers or ribbons decorate the text. Two of these, the second of which contains a single loop, extend from the ascenders in the words "and" and "thirty" of line 2. Another vine- like streamer, interrupted by the "i" of "since," ornaments the space between lines 2 and 3; the first word of line 8 begins, and the final word of line 9 terminates, with this motif.
A feather, plume, or leaf curves above the words "heaven is begun" in line 2.

Resembling on a smaller scale the fire-engulfed female of the plate's major design, a small figure, possibly a gowned female, hovers above the second and third words of line 2, her arms and body horizontal.
A small figure, perhaps the male counterpart to the gowned female of line 2, hovers above "Adam" in line 7, his arms and body horizontal.
At the end of line 10, two figures, possibly a male and gowned female, stand or stride facing each other and holding hands on a vine-like arabesque.
At the end of line 10, two figures, possibly a male and gowned female, stand facing each other and holding hands on a vine-like arabesque.
A bird with extended wings flies above "three" in line 3.

lg.l: As a new heaven is begun, and it is now thir-
-ty-three years since its advent: the Eternal Hell
revives. And lo! Swedenborg is the Angel sitting
at the tomb; his writings are the linen clothes folded
up. Now is the dominion of Edom, & the return of
Adam into Paradise; see Isaiah XXXIV & XXXV Chap:
Without Contraries is no progression. Attraction
and Repulsion, Reason and Energy, Love and
Hate, are necessary to Human existence.
From these contraries spring what the religious call
Good & Evil. Good is the passive that obeys Reason
Evil is the active springing from Energy.
Good is Heaven. Evil is Hell,

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design repeats the strong left-right divisions of the lower title page and the lower design on Plate 3. In most copies, the figures hover above the sea, but the green coloring on the left and the blue on the right in this copy suggests a distinction between grassy land and sea with a large wave at the shoreline. Perhaps continuing the saga begun at the bottom of Plate 3, a nude male with curly hair hovers against a background of flames. His right ankle is shackled and chained. On the left, running or flying over the land(?), with a sun behind, is a nude figure of indeterminate sex holding a child. One of the color prints of this subject is inscribed by Blake "The Good & Evil Angels" (Butlin nos. 323-24).

component.illusobjdesc: On the left, running or flying over grassy land or green water with left foot foremost, a sun behind, is a nude figure of indeterminate sex, holding a child with his or her left arm. According to Blake's later inscription on a color print, the figure may be a "good angel" ("The Good & Evil Angels," Butlin nos. 323-24).
A nude child or infant, legs spread and arms raised vertically, is held by the figure on the left. The child has curly hair and would seem to be looking up.

An apparently male nude figure with arms raised horizontally hovers over water against a background of flames. He faces to the left; his hair is curly. His right leg is shackled and chained (insubstantially to the water below?). According to Blake's later inscription on a color print, he may be an "evil angel" ("The Good & Evil Angels," Butlin nos. 323-24).
The right leg of the figure is bound with a shackle; at least two links in a chain descends below the shackle toward the water below.
A sun shines in the background over the water. Radiance and beams of light emanate from it.

Water, perhaps a sea, extends from left to right margin in most copies. In this copy, however, the green coloring on the left and blue on the right suggests a distinction between grassy land and water, with a large wave at the shoreline.
The green coloring of the land(?) suggests grass. Alternatively, this may only be green water.
The figure on the right hovers against a background of flames.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Numerous interlinear designs ornament the plate. A heraldic vignette announces "The voice of the Devil" (lines 2-3): three angels blow their trumpets on either side of these lines. To the left of the text, two of the angels—one gowned, the other apparently nude—face up and left; to the right of the text, the third angel, also gowned, mirrors its companions, facing up and right. A looped, vine-like extension grows from the ascender of "all" in line 4. Beside the lone angel on the right, a vine rises from the first letter of "been" in line 4; alternatively, one might interpret the motif (in spite of the green tinting) as a bird, flying left, whose tail touches the ascender of "been." Its fantastic plume contains a single loop, a feature that continues the vegetative motif of the scene. To the right of the vine or bird ascends a smaller winged creature, either a bird or an insect, and to its left, three leaf-like flags extend from the "d" of "sacred" and the "h" of "have" in line 4. These flags may represent the musical notes of the trumpeters, although their green coloring in this copy emphasizes their vegetable nature. Below the winged bird or insect, at the end of line 5, are two hovering figures facing each other, a gowned female on the left and a child or infant on the right. Further down, to the right of line 6, a small figure, its body and arms horizontal, flees from a recumbent figure on a leaf. Next to the words "the Soul" in line 10 are seven figures in sundry positions. There may be two huddled figures facing each other. The figure on the right in this group crouches or squats, reaching an arm out to its companion. They are followed by two tiny figures hovering and facing each other. They may be holding hands. The hand-holding figures hover above a vine- like streamer extending from the "M" of "Man" in line 11. Next to this pair, three figures huddle together on some vegetation consisting of leaves and/or tufts of grass. Following the word "Energies" in line 12 are four figures and two animals: the first animal, perhaps a horse, kicks up its back heels. Next to it stand two children holding hands, followed by another hand-holding pair, a child and an adult. The latter extends his left arm horizontally, perhaps pointing to the ox which grazes nearby on a bit of tableland. An ornamental ribbon, most likely vegetative in nature, closes the vignette. Further down the plate, three leaves grow from the "B" of "But" in line 13. A branch with spiky leaves grows from the "e" of "age" in line 17. Following it, a horizontal figure hovers above a wispy line, suggesting a cirrus-like cloud. The figure raises its arm, seemingly in an effort to make contact with the adjacent figure, who hovers, legs spread and one arm reaching to the left, above a line of vegetation. To the right, a man walks a small dog on a leash. The forms on each side of the man and dog may be the stumps of trees. Facing left, a lumbering figure, bearded or blindfolded, walks (runs?) in a contorted position, viz., bending forward from the waist with one arm outstretched in front of him. Mimicking his general posture, an anthropomorphic tree arches to the left. Near the margin between lines 18 and 19 stands a small figure, possibly holding a cane. Six or seven figures observe another figure one line down. With legs slightly apart and arms raised, it appears to address its audience. To its back is either a tree with a disproportionally large branch or leaf. Concluding the procession, two horses, the second of which is indicated merely by some faint profile lines, pull a figure in its cart. Background coloring suggests sky, perhaps as a continuation of the major design below the text.

component.illusobjdesc: Background coloring in the text area suggests sky, perhaps as a continuation of the major design below the text. The yellow tinting on the right hints at a sunrise or sunset.

Three angels blow their trumpets on either side of lines 2-3, "The voice of the Devil." To the left of the text, two of the angels—one gowned, the other nude—face up and left; to the right of the text, the third angel, also gowned, mirrors its companions, facing up and right.
Each of the three angels blows a trumpet.
Next to the lone angel on the right side of the plate is a vine that hints at the shape of a bird flying. The vine has at least one loop and perhaps a leaf or two.
The ambiguous motif next to the lone angel on the right side of the plate may be a bird (in spite of the green tinting in this copy) that flies left. Its fantastic plume contains a single loop.
A double-looped, serpentine vine grows from the ascender of "All" in line 4.
To the right of and below the vine or bird touching the ascender of "been" in line 4, a smaller bird, or possibly an insect, soars upwards on extended wings.
Below the winged bird or insect, at the end of line 5, a gowned female hovers, facing right. Reaching her arms out toward a child or infant, she nearly touches its hands. Her body is horizontal.

Positioned slightly above its mother(?), the child or infant, facing left and down, descends in her direction at an angle. Its little arms appear outstretched, as though it reaches toward her. The child may be falling through the air.
Three leaf-like flags extend from the "d" of "sacred" and the "h" of "have" in line 4.

Because they resemble the plumage of the bird to their right, the flags extending from the "d" of "sacred" and the "h" of "have" in line 4 may represent feathers; alternatively, they might signify the musical notes of the trumpeters flanking lines 2-3.
To the right of line 7 is a small figure, its body and arms horizontal; it faces left, perhaps fleeing from the recumbent figure on a leaf.
Facing left at the end of line 7, a recumbent figure reclines on a leaf.
The figure at the end of line 7 reclines on a large leaf.
Two figures huddle together following the text of line 10. The other figure sits facing left with hunched shoulders.

Following the huddled shapes right of line 10, two figures hover above a streamer, holding hands. Their bodies are horizontal. In contrast to the legs of the figure on the right, which are spread apart, those of the other figure are obscured, perhaps covered by a gown or drapery of some sort, or else simply positioned together.
The hand-holding figures hover above a vine-like streamer extending from the "M" of "Man" in line 11.

Next to the hand-holding figures following the text of line 10, three figures huddle together on some vegetation consisting of leaves and/or tufts of grass. They appear to face right, forward, and left, respectively, though the direction of the second figure is ambiguous in Copy G. The figures flanking the middle shape clearly have their legs drawn up, heads resting on knees, shoulders hunched.
Three figures at the end of line 10 huddle together on some vegetation consisting of leaves and/or tufts of grass.
Following the word "Energies" in line 12 are four figures and two animals: the first animal, perhaps a horse, kicks up its back heels, facing away from the children on the right.
Next to the horse(?) stand two children holding hands.
Beside the children, two figures—a child and an adult who appears to be male—stand holding hands. The man extends his left arm horizontally, perhaps pointing to the nearby ox.
Not far from the child and adult who hold hands to the right of line 12, an ox grazes on a bit of tableland.
An ornamental ribbon to the right of the ox at the end of line 12 seemingly represents a stylized leaf.

Bits of vegetation appear passim, ornamenting the plate: in the left margin of line 6 is the outline of a small leaf(?) unattached to a letter. Further down, a leaf adorns the "B" of "But" in line 13. At the end of line 14, a vine- or leaf-like serif extends from the "l" of "Soul."
A branch with spiky leaves grows from the "e" of "age" in line 17.

Following the branch with spiky leaves right of line 17, an amorphous, horizontal figure hovers—facing right—above a wispy cloud. The figure extends its arm, perhaps in an effort to make contact with the adjacent figure.
The first figure of line 16 hovers above a wispy line, which suggests a cirrus-like cloud.
Facing left, a figure prepares to leave its vegetative bed. One of its legs extends backward. At least one arm is outstretched, reaching in the direction of the adjacent figure.
To the right of line 17, a figure prepares to leave its vegetative bed, which resembles a branch growing from the "l" of "life" in line 18.
Following "age" in line 17, a man—the third figure from the left—walks a small dog, which appears to be on a leash.
The third figure from the left following "age" in line 17 is a man walking a small dog. The dog appears to be on a leash.
The forms right and left of the man with a dog may be the stumps of trees.

Headed in the direction of the tree stump below "Soul" in line 16, a lumbering figure, bearded or blindfolded, walks (runs?) in a contorted position, viz., hunched over and bent forward from the waist with at least one arm outstretched in front of him.
Mimicking the general posture of the bearded or blindfolded figure below "Soul" in line 17, an anthropomorphic tree with leafless branches for arms and a trunk for a torso arches to the left.
In the left margin between lines 18 and 19, a small figure walks or stands, possibly holding a staff or walking- stick.
At line 20, a group of six or seven figures observes an eighth figure. In contrast to the others, who appear to be standing, the second and third figures from the left may be sitting.
With legs slightly apart and arms extended, the last figure of the group following "Energy" in line 20 appears to address its audience.
To the back of the animated figure right of line 20 is a tree with a disproportionally large branch or leaf.
Concluding the procession of figures, two horses, the second of which is indicated merely by some faint profile lines, pull a coachman in his cart or chariot.
Concluding the procession at the end of line 20, two horses pull a coachman in his cart or chariot. The rider's extended arms presumably hold reins, though none are readily discernible.

lg.l: All Bibles or sacred codes. have been
the causes of the following Errors.
1. That Man has two real existing princi-
-ples Viz: a Body & a Soul.
2. That Energy. calld Evil. is alone from the
Body. & that Reason. calld Good. is alone from
the Soul.
3. That God will torment Man in Eternity
for following his Energies.
But the following Contraries to these are True
1 Man has no Body distinct from his Soul
for that calld Body is a portion of Soul discernd
by the five Senses, the chief inlets of Soul in this
age
2. Energy is the only life and is from the Body
and Reason is the bound or outward circumference
of Energy.
3 Energy is Eternal Delight

illustration.illusobjdesc: The nude male with outspread limbs, falling into flames with his sword, robe, chariot, cannonball (or a planet or the moon?), and horse, may represent "the Devils account" (line 16) of the war in heaven: that "the Messiah fell. & formed a heaven of what he stole from the Abyss" (Plate 5, line 16-17; Plate 6, line 2-3), though several other identifications are possible. The flames and smoke on the right are particularly dense in this copy, almost suggesting an overhanging cliff.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male with arms raised vertically and legs spread falls headfirst into flames. His fingers are spread apart, at least on his right hand. He may represent Christ, as "the Messiah" who "fell. & formed a heaven of what he stole from the Abyss" (Plate 5, line 16-17; Plate 6, line 2-3).
A sword falls alongside the figure into flames.
A broken wheel, the remains of a chariot, falls.
A robe or cloak that presumably belongs to either the male on the left or the horse on the right falls into flames. In this copy, the robe tends to merge with the chariot wheel.
A horse that presumably belongs with the chariot whose wheel is falling in the middle of this design falls headfirst into flames.
A round object, probably a cannonball though perhaps a planet or the moon (note the hint of a crescent-shaped shadow), falls into flames.
Flames lick up from the bottom edge of the design. The flames and smoke are particularly dense on the right in this copy, almost suggesting an overhanging cliff. Wisps of smoke appear upper left.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several vine-like extensions adorn the letters of the text: the most elaborate of these is the looped tendril growing from the "T" of "Those" in line 2. Five figures in various postures ornament the plate. A figure lies on the ground, propped up on one arm, following line 4. At the end of line 6, a figure lies supine in a few tufts of grass. Beneath the words "Paradise Lost" in line 7 are two more figures facing each other. The figure on the left may be writing; the other appears to be holding a pair of compasses. Some serpentine vegetation extends behind this seated figure. In the left margin of line 9, a small figure walks or runs with outstretched arms. A bird or winged serpent with a loopy, serpentine tail soars at the end of line 11. Following "Satan" in line 13, a serpent spans nearly the width of the plate. Its mouth is open and its forked tongue is extended. A small branch with spiky leaves appears in the bottom left margin. Green tinting just above the bottom margin of the plate suggests grass; blue tinting in the right margin suggests sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Several vine-like extensions adorn the letters of the text: the most elaborate of these is the looped tendril growing from the "T" of "Those" in line 2. Also notable is the vegetative ascender of "who" in line 2.
a figure lies on the ground, propped up on one arm, following line 4. We may be seeing the figure from behind; its head may be twisted to face left.
Following line 6 and just above "Los" in line 7, a figure lies supine in a few tufts of grass. Its arms are raised horizontally and its legs are slightly apart.
The figure at the end of line 6 lies supine amidst a few tufts of grass.
Beneath the words "Paradise Lost" in line 7 are two figures facing each other. The one reclining on the left is gowned and holds what appears to be a writing implement in its hand.
The reclining figure holds an implement, perhaps a pen, in its hand.
Across from the reclining figure, a second figure sits in a chair or on a stool (or kneels beside the object) with its head bent over a pair of twin compasses.
The figure sits with its head bent over a pair of twin compasses.
Bent over its pair of compasses, the figure sits in a chair or on a stool (or kneels beside the object).

The two figures at the end of line 8 are flanked by vegetation. To the left of the reclining figure is a curve resembling a leaf. Behind the seated figure extends a vine-like or serpentine vegetative motif.
In the left margin of line 9, a small figure, facing left, walks or runs with extended arms. Its general posture recalls that of the blind or bearded figure from the previous plate.

At the end of line 11 soars a creature on extended bat- like wings. It has been variously identified as a bird, a hybrid bird/serpent, and a dragon. The looped extension of the animal may be a serpentine tail. Alternatively, it could represent a serpent dangling from the talons of the bird, anticipating the major design of Plate 12, which depicts an eagle gripping a coiled serpent in its talons.
Following "Satan" in line 13, a serpent spans nearly the width of the plate. A forked tongue protrudes from its open mouth.
A small branch with spiky leaves appears in the bottom left margin of the plate, next to lines 14 and 15.
Green tinting just above the bottom of the plate suggests grass.
Blue tinting in the right margin of the text suggests sky.

lg.l: Those who restrain desire, do so because theirs
is weak enough to be restrained; and the restrainer or
reason usurps its place & governs the unwilling.
And being restraind it by degrees becomes passive
till it is only the shadow of desire.
The history of this is written in Paradise Lost. & the
Governor or Reason is call'd Messiah.
And the original Archangel or possessor of the com-
-mand of the heavenly host, is call'd the Devil or Satan
and his children are call'd Sin & Death
But in the Book of Job Miltons Messiah is call'd
Satan.
For this history has been adopted by both parties
It indeed appear'd to Reason as if Desire was
cast out, but the Devils account is, that the Messi-

objnote.p: In line 7, a letter (before 'he') and at least one word (after 'he') were deleted from the plate. Erdman suggests that the line originally read 'the Devil who' or, less probably, 'the Angel who' (Erdman page 801).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Following the word "Abyss" in line 3 is a vignette that spans nearly the width of the plate. A curved line might be a plant bent almost to the ground. To the right of an indeterminate form, perhaps another plant also bent low, a hovering figure with extended arms holds an indeterminate object. Another figure, also with outstretched arms, reaches in the direction of the first figure. A vine-like, serpentine tail or vegetative motif extends behind it. Various other vegetative motifs, sometimes growing from letters, adorn the plate. At the end of line 8, a gowned figure hangs suspended from the "g" of "flaming." As "The voice of the Devil" (Plate 4, lines 2-3) is bracketed by a pair of heralds with trumpets, "A Memorable Fancy" (line 15) is bracketed by an upright gowned figure rising from the flames (left) and an upside-down figure falling into them (right). Poised above the "w" of "walking" in line 16 is a figure with arms raised horizontally and one leg extended backward. At the bottom of the plate, blue coloring and some spiky forms suggest a stormy sea or sky with clouds and perhaps a bolt of lightning. Fragments of letters seem to be emerging on the left: most likely "HOW," (first letter not clear in this copy [line 27]) which begins the devil's question, "How do you know," as written with corroding fires on the sides of the rock and "now percieved by the minds of men" (Plate 7, lines 2-5). Background tinting throughout the plate suggests sky, possibly with a sunrise or sunset in the lower half of the plate.

component.illusobjdesc: Following the word "Abyss" in line 3, a plant leans to the right, nearly touching the ground. Further to the right is an object that may be another plant, with two leaves, also bent low.
Following the two plant(?) right of line 3, a hovering figure with extended arms holds an indeterminate object, which it seems to offer to the figure on the right.

Facing left, a second figure adopts a half-kneeling or lunging position, with one leg bent at the knee and head apparently bent downward. Arms extended, it seems to reach for the indeterminate object held by the first figure. Behind it extends a loopy vine-like, serpentine tail or vegetative motif.
The loopy vine-like or serpentine extension may be a continuation of the strip of vegetative surface that follows "Abyss" in line 3.

At the end of line 8, a small figure hangs suspended from, grasps, or touches the loop of the "g" in "flaming" (line 7). Its arms are nearly horizontal. The squiggly extension of the figure's gown continues the serpentine ornamentation found passim in the various interlinear designs.
To the left of the inscription, "A Memorable Fancy" (line 15), a gowned figure with right arm raised horizontally and left arm raised vertically runs above, or rises from, flames.
To the right of the inscription, a (nude?) figure with arms raised horizontally falls headfirst into flames.
Flames extend from left to right margin just below the inscription, "A Memorable Fancy" (line 15).
Poised above the "w" of "walking" in line 16, a hovering figure faces right with arms raised horizontally and one leg extended backward.

Numerous vegetative motifs adorn the plate. Attached to the "B" of "But" in line 9 is a small leaf. Two lines down, the "N" of "Note" has a leaf- or vine-like flourish. Two more leaves(?) follow "garments" in line 22. The extension of "When" in line 23 nearly forms a loop. Several of the letters in "A Memorable Fancy" (line 15) have vine- or flame-like extensions, including the "F" and "y" of "Fancy." The letter "A" is particularly elaborate: its looped extension terminates in three curved lines suggestive of twigs or branches. Near the word "it" in line 14, a vine or narrow leaf extends behind flames almost to the right margin.
Just above the lower margin of the plate, blue washes and spiky lines suggest a stormy sea or sky with large waves or clouds and perhaps a bolt of lightning.
Background coloring throughout the plate suggests sky, possibly with a sunrise or sunset in the lower half of the plate.

lg.l: HOW

component.illusobjdesc: Lower left, a few fragments of letters seem to be emerging: most likely "HOW" (line 27), which begins the devil's question, "How do you know," as written with corroding fires on the sides of the rock and "now percieved by the minds of men" (Plate 7, lines 2-5). The initial letter is unclear in this copy.

lg.l: -ah fell. & formed a heaven of what he stole from the
Abyss
This is shewn in the Gospel, where he prays to the
Father to send the comforter or Desire that Reason
may have Ideas to build on, the Jehovah of the Bible

being no other than he who dwells in flaming fireA letter (before 'he') and at least one word (after 'he') were deleted from the plate. Erdman suggests that the line originally read 'the Devil who' or, less probably, 'the Angel who' (Erdman page 801).
Know that after Christs death, he became Jehovah.
But in Milton; the Father is Destiny, the Son, a
Ratio of the five senses. & the Holy-ghost, Vacuum!
Note. The reason Milton wrote in fetters when
he wrote of Angels & God, and at liberty when of
Devils & Hell, is because he was a true Poet and
of the Devils party without knowing it
As I was walking among the fires of hell, de-
-lighted with the enjoyments of Genius; which to An-
-gels look like torment and insanity. I collected some
of their Proverbs: thinking that as the sayings used
in a nation, mark its character, so the Proverbs of
Hell, shew the nature of Infernal wisdom better
than any description of buildings or garments
When I came home; on the abyss of the five sen-
-ses. where a flat sided steep frowns over the pre-
-sent world. I saw a mighty Devil folded in black
clouds. hovering on the sides of the rock, with cor-
HOWro-

illustration.illusobjdesc: The balance of the interlinear designs, which are frequently emphasized with blue washes suggesting sky, appear in the right margin of the plate. Flanking "Proverbs of Hell" (line 6) are two vignettes. To the left of the inscription, beneath a tree with long, drooping branches, a gowned figure bends forward from the waist. In its hand is an implement of some kind, usually identified as a stick or dibble. To the right of "Hell," a nearly erect serpent faces two figures, an adult and a child, both of whom have raised arms. The form to the right, another child in other copies, is uncertain in this copy. Next to the right are the trunk of a tree(?) and perhaps a plant. Further down, in the right margin, a male runs right, his arm extended in front of him and one leg extended behind him. To the left are leaves and/or grass. Next to "you" at the end of line 24, a loopy vine-like or serpentine motif curves up and to the left. At the bottom right of the plate, a gowned trumpeter hovers amongst what may be clouds tinted by a sunrise or sunset. Various letter extensions ornament the plate: the most notable of these is the many-looped tendril, suggestive of a spiral, that grows from the "H" of "How" in line 4.

component.illusobjdesc: The plate's interlinear vignettes are emphasized with blue washes suggesting sky.
A tree with long, drooping branches, some of which arch over a bent figure, appears to the left of the inscription, "Proverbs of Hell," in line 6. The tree may be leafless in this copy.

A gowned figure facing right and/or down bends forward from the waist. In its hand the figure holds an implement, which is sometimes identified, with reference to the first proverb, as a stick or dibble for planting seeds.
In its hand the figure holds an implement, which is sometimes identified, with reference to the first proverb, as a stick or dibble for planting seeds.
To the right of "Hell" in line 6, a nearly erect serpent faces right, leaning slightly forward. With mouth open, it appears to address the three figures who stand nearby.
In the right margin at the end of line 6, an adult and a child stand looking at the nearby serpent. In other copies, the form to the right is another child, but the motif is uncertain in this copy.
The second figure right of the serpent, gowned, may be a female, perhaps the mother of the child to the left. Standing with arms raised horizontally, she appears to look forward or two the left.
Just right of the serpent is a child, arms raised vertically. The child may be facing forward or left and looking at the serpent.
To the right of the figures is an indeterminate form (a child in other copies) and what may be the trunk of a tree and some indeterminate vegetation, perhaps a plant of some sort.

Following "plow" in line 8, a male runs(?), facing right. One of his legs extends backward, and his arm, bent at the elbow, extends in front of him. He may be wearing tights, as indicated by yellow tinting on his body and on his legs above the knees.
Behind the nude figure are some leaves or tufts of grass. The object right of this running figure may be more vegetation or a hill or cliff.
The sloping surface in front of the nude figure may represent the side of a hill or the edge of a cliff.
Next to "you" at the end of line 24, a double-looped, serpentine vine or tendril curves up and to the left.

In the bottom right corner of the plate is a vignette that includes a gowned trumpeter (recalling the heraldic angels of Plate 4). Hovering or flying amidst the clouds, the figure faces left and up, possibly ascending through the air.
The gowned figure at the bottom right corner of the plate blows a trumpet.
Clouds appear below and to the left of the trumpeter, perhaps tinted by a sunrise or sunset.

Various letter extensions and vegetative motifs adorn the plate passim. The most notable of these is the many-looped tendril or vine, suggestive of a spiral, that grows from the "H" of "How" in line 4. In the same line, the vine-like descender of "airy" has a single loop. The "H" of "Hell" in line 6 sports a streamer resembling a vine. Further down, a vine-like or serpentine ornament connects the initial words in lines 18 and 20.
The many-looped extension growing from the "H" of "How" in line 4 resembles a spiral.

lg.l: -roding fires he wrote the following sentence now per-
-cieved by the minds of men, & read by them on earth.
How do you know but ev'ry Bird that cuts the airy way,
Is an immense world of delight, clos'd by your senses five?
In seed time learn, in harvest teach, in winter enjoy.
Drive your cart and your plow over the bones of the dead.
The road of excess leads to the palace of wisdom.
Prudence is a rich ugly old maid courted by Incapacity.
He who desires but acts not, breeds pestilence.
The cut worm forgives the plow.
Dip him in the river who loves water.
A fool sees not the same tree that a wise man sees.
He whose face gives no light, shall never become a star.
Eternity is in love with the productions of time.
The busy bee has no time for sorrow.
The hours of folly are measur'd by the clock, but of wis-
-dom: no clock can measure.
All wholsom food is caught without a net or a trap.
Bring out number weight & measure in a year of dearth.
No bird soars too high. if he soars with his own wings.
A dead body. revenges not injuries.
The most sublime act is to set another before you.
If the fool would persist in his folly he would become
Folly is the cloke of knavery.wise
Shame is Prides cloke.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vegetative motifs flank the plate's second line, "Proverbs of Hell": to the left of the words is a leafy vine; following "Hell," a many-looped tendril of a grapevine descends toward the leafy vine right of line 4. The grapevine motif is reproduced elsewhere, and various leaves, buds, serpentine vines and/or flowers adorn the plate passim. Dangling from the end of line 5 is a cluster of grapes. Further down, in the right margin, a flock of birds soars on extended wings. A detached vine or branch with leaves appears in the general space occupied by the birds, coinciding with one of their wings. Line 16 is teeming with small-scale designs: An eagle, lion, two figures, and some grazing sheep appear in close proximity to one another. Below, next to "rod" in line 19, a small figure, perhaps a child, peers up at a vaguely anthropomorphic tree. Following "fruits" in line 23 is a vine with leaves. To the right, numerous birds fly above a picturesque seascape, complete with boats or ships, and a tree grows from the side of a cliff overlooking the water. Two lines down, a coiled snake faces a leaping stag. A grapevine with leaves follows line 30. Blue and rose washes suggest sky, possibly at sunrise or sunset. The yellow washes variously suggest both earth and sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Blue and rose washes suggest sky, possibly at sunrise or sunset. The yellow washes variously suggest both earth and sky.
To the left of the plate's second line, "Proverbs of Hell," are several leaves—perhaps grape or oak—attached to a thin branch or vine.
Following "Hell," a five-looped tendril of a grapevine descends toward a leafy vine right of line 5.
The five-looped tendril of the grapevine to the left of the inscription is suggestive of a spiral.

The grapevine motif is reproduced elsewhere, and various leaves, buds, flowers, and/or serpentine vines adorn the plate passim. At the beginning of line 4, a few scattered leaves cling to slender stems. In the right margin—about a fourth of the way down the plate— is a single leaf attached to a double-looped tendril of a grapevine. A serpentine version of this motif (leaves grace an undulating rather than a loopy vine) appears on the bottom right of the plate. Another snake- like, curvy vine extends below the "The" at the beginning of line 10. To the left of "the sheep" in line 16, a few buds or leaves grow from a delicate stem. Leaves(?) precede the words "the lion" in line 22. Further down, at the beginning of line 27, are more vaguely-delineated leaves.
Descending from the end of line 5, a cluster of grapes is attached to a single-looped vine.
At the ends of lines 12-14, a flock of four birds soars on extended wings. One bird sports a particularly long, forked tail.
A detached vine or branch with scanty leaves appears in the general space occupied by the birds, coinciding with the wing of the inside bird.
An eagle flies forward on extended wings next to "sheep" in line 16. Its head is tilted up and to the left, and its beak may be open.
A lion, walking right, looks over its shoulder in the direction of the eagle.

Following the text of line 16 are two figures flanked by a lion and sheep. They are usually identified as a male and female who illustrate the proverb, "Let man wear the fell of the lion, woman the fleece of the sheep" (lines 15-16). The male figure on the left lies semi-prone on the ground, his right arm bent as he props himself up on his elbows. He appears to look down.
The female figure, facing left and down, adopts a half- crawling, half-kneeling posture: her hands are on the ground, her shoulders and back hunched.
Three(?) mammals, presumably sheep, graze at the far right of line 16.
Positioned at the ends of lines 19 and 20, a small figure, perhaps a child, gazes up at a vaguely anthropomorphic tree. The child's arms are extended.
Next to the child is a leafless, anthropomorphic tree, with branches for arms.
A vine with leaves (or at least one very large leaf) follows the text of line 23.
A third of the way up from the bottom right of the plate is a picturesque seascape. A flock of birds flies above the water.
The sea is represented by a wash of blue color.
Two or three boats or ships navigate the water. The boats on the horizon (right) and on the left are under sail.
A tree with spreading leaves grows from the side of a cliff overlooking the water.
A cliff rises right of the water.
Following the text of line 27, a coiled snake faces right.
Facing left, a stag leaps or lunges in the direction of the coiled snake.

lg.l: Prisons are built with stones of Law, Brothels with
bricks of Religion.
The pride of the peacock is the glory of God.
The lust of the goat is the bounty of God.
The wrath of the lion is the wisdom of God.
The nakedness of woman is the work of God.
Excess of sorrow laughs. Excess of joy weeps.
The roaring of lions, the howling of wolves, the raging
of the stormy sea. and the destructive sword. are
portions of eternity too great for the eye of man.
The fox condemns the trap, not himself.
Joys impregnate, Sorrows bring forth.
Let man wear the fell of the lion. woman the fleece of
the sheep.
The bird a nest. the spider a web. man friendship.
The selfish smiling fool. & the sullen frowning fool. shall
be both thought wise, that they may be a rod.
What is now proved was once, only imagin'd.
The rat, the mouse, the fox, the rabbet; watch the roots,
the lion, the tyger. the horse, the elephant, watch
the fruits,
The cistern contains; the fountain overflows
One thought, fills immensity.
Always be ready to speak your mind, and a base man
will avoid you.
Every thing possible to be believ'd is an image of truth.
The eagle never lost so much time. as when he submit-
-ted to learn of the crow.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Most of the interlinear designs are concentrated at the top of the plate, where they flank line 2, "Proverbs of Hell." Numerous vegetative swirls, usually vine-like or serpentine, appear in this location, as well as elsewhere on the plate. Following the first of such swirls left of line 2 is a leaping or hovering infant or child with legs spread. To the right of the text in the same line, a figure reclines in a vegetative hammock in several other copies, but in this copy the green tinting obscures any such figure and converts the motif into a curved vine. In the bottom right corner of the plate, a couple hovers against a backdrop of sky. Elsewhere throughout the plate, washes suggest a sky at sunrise or sunset, perhaps with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: Throughout the plate, washes suggest a sky at sunrise or sunset, perhaps with clouds.

Numerous vegetative swirls, often vine-like or serpentine, adorn the plate. Several of these flank the plate's second line, "Proverbs of Hell." The attached swirls in the upper left corner resemble stylized leaves. The squiggles to the immediate left of "Proverbs" are particularly vine- or snake-like. Other variations on this design appear to the right of "Hell." Further down, a swirl curves around the second part of the hyphenated "instruction" at the end of line 9. The motif continues to the left of line 11, where another swirl introduces the text. A vine with one loop extends from the first letter of "The" at the beginning of line 15.

To the left of the inscription in line 2, a nude child or infant hovers, facing left. Its leg extends backward, and the viewer sees the figure from behind. The child seems to point in the general direction of the text of line 3.

A couple hovers in the lower right corner of the plate. The figures face up and right, ascending through the air. Each has one arms raised at 135 degrees, as if pointing or reaching. The male (on the left) extends one leg backward. The female (on the right) is gowned and has her other arm raised horizontally.

lg.l: The fox provides for himself, but God provides for the lion.
Think in the morning. Act in the noon, Eat in the even-
-ing, Sleep in the night,
He who has sufferd you to impose on him knows you.
As the plow follows words, so God rewards prayers.
The tygers of wrath are wiser than the horses of in-
Expect poison from the standing water. -struction
You never know what is enough unless you know what is
more than enough.
Listen to the fools reproach! it is a kingly title!
The eyes of fire, the nostrils of air, the mouth of water,
the beard of earth.
The weak in courage is strong in cunning.
The apple tree never asks the beech how he shall grow,
nor the lion, the horse, how he shall take his prey.
The thankful reciever bears a plentiful harvest.
If others had not been foolish, we should be so.
The soul of sweet delight, can never be defil'd,
When thou seest an Eagle, thou seest a portion of Ge
-nius. lift up thy head!
As the catterpiller chooses the fairest leaves to lay
her eggs on, so the priest lays his curse on
the fairest joys.
To create a little flower is the labour of ages.
Damn, braces: Bless relaxes.
The best wine is the oldest. the best water the newest.
Prayers plow not! Praises reap not!
Joys laugh not! Sorrows weep not!

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude male devil with bat wings, pointing to a scroll across his lap, kneels between two seated scribes. A gowned figure (probably male) to the left apparently writes down what he says and a second gowned figure (probably male) to the right looks over his shoulder and copies from the scroll to the tablet in his lap. All three figures are on grassy ground with flames below and on each side. Behind the central devil is a table or stool covered with something, perhaps a cushion. Spiky vegetation—a plant of some sort—frames the figures on the right; the threatening plant on the left might be a catchfly. Blue sky appears above and behind the figures.

component.illusobjdesc: A seated, gowned figure with short curly hair, probably male, writes on a tablet(?), as if taking dictation from the central figure.
A devil, a nude and with short, curly hair and bat-like wings, kneels while pointing at a scroll across his lap. He turns his head toward a scribe to the left, as if telling the scribe what to write.

A gowned figure with short, curly hair, probably male, sits with his legs spread and his legs or ankles crossed. He writes or poises to write on a tablet or scroll in his lap, perhaps copying from the scroll in the lap of the central figure, though with head turned as if looking directly left.
The figures are surrounded on three sides by flames.
Green tinting suggests grass below the figures.
Behind the central figure is a table or stool covered with something, perhaps a cushion.
A spiky, rather threatening looking plant grows left of the figure on the left. It may be a catchfly, which Blake might have seen in the works of Erasmus Darwin.

At far right is a spiky plant, perhaps a gloriosa superba, that Blake might have seen in the work of Erasmus Darwin. From it rises a tendril perhaps copied from another plant in Darwin, vallisneria spiralis.
In the lap of the central figure is a an unfurled scroll that ends in a spiral coil on the right.
In the laps of each of the scribes who flank the central figure is a surface to write on, probably a tablet or scroll (right figure).
Each of the scribes who flanks the central figure holds a pen(?) in his right hand.
Blue sky appears above and behind the figures.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Golden washes, variously suggesting sky or earth, reinforce the interlinear designs. Vegetative motifs flank the plate's second line, "Proverbs of Hell." The grape leaf to the immediate right of "Hell" reappears above line 18, where it is attached to a looped tendril. Other vegetative designs adorn the plate passim: a long, slender branch with leaves or buds follows "contemptible" in line 6; a plant and a leaf(?) follow line 14; some flame-like leaves appear in the right margin above "and" in line 16 (integrated, in this copy, with the flames from the major design); and a leaf appears left of line 17. To the left of "Enough! or Too much" in line 18 is a small sprig of ivy. Numerous figures populate the plate, all of which are concentrated in the spaces following the text of lines 8 and 14. After line 8, four figures appear. Of these, two face each other; at least the lower figure appears to be lying on the ground or on a cloud. A third figure, adjacent to the other pair, lies supine(?) on a gentle slope, which resembles a cloud. To the right, the last figure of this group raises its arms horizontally and extends one leg backward. The second group of figures—after line 14—begins (left) with a hovering figure holding a leaf(?). Behind it is an infant or small child, who is followed by a man and woman, as well as two birds.

component.illusobjdesc: The grape leaf assumes some prominence among the interlinear designs on this plate: two appear to the right of line 2, "Proverbs of Hell." The words "not be believ'd" in line 17 are followed by a grape leaf attached to a looped tendril, suggestive of a spiral. The leaf introducing line 17 may also be grape.

Other botanical motifs ornament the plate. To the left of "Proverbs" (line 2) is a cluster of leaves on a vine or branch. Preceding "Enough! or Too Much" in line 18 is a branch of ivy(?). More stylized vegetative designs appear passim: a leaf- or vine-like swirl curves around "As" in line 5. A long, slender branch with buds or leaves, recalling a similar motif on Plate 8, stretches to the right margin following the word "contemptible" in line 6. Two lines down (line 8), in the left margin, a small sprig of buds or leaves—perhaps a detachment from the longer branch described above—also vaguely resembles the tendril rising from the gloriosa superba of the major design. At the end of line 14, in the general vicinity of the plate's second group of interlinear figures, are a plant, perhaps bearing a grain tassel, and a leaf(?) held by a hovering figure. Further to the right, near the right margin, are some flame-like leaves just above "and" in line 16 which, in this copy, are integrated with the fire from the major design below.
Next to "white" in line 8 is a vignette consisting of four figures in sundry postures above curving lines apparently indicating earth and/or clouds.

Two nude figures, a male and female(?), face each other. The lower figure apparently lies on the ground or on a cloud. Their bodies are horizontal. The upper figure, a male seen from behind, has his arms raised horizontally; his companion's position is uncertain.
To the right of the couple hovering in the air, a nude figure lies supine(?) on the ground or on a cloud. The figure's lower body is tilted slightly toward the viewer; its legs are together.
Its foot wedged in the crease of a cloud(?), the fourth figure of the vignette faces left. Its arms are raised horizontally and one leg extends backward.
Yellow washes suggest sky—or perhaps earth in a few areas.
The curved lines right of line 8 may represent earth and/or clouds.
A group of four figures appears to the right of "desires" in line 14.
Facing left and down, a hovering figure right of line 14 holds what might be a leaf. The figure's legs are spread apart.
A small infant or child follows the figure holding a leaf. Hovering in the air, the child faces left. Its arms are raised nearly vertically, and one of its legs extends backward.
Adjacent to the small child on the left, a man and woman face right. The male has one arm raise at 135 degrees, the other bent upward, possibly to hold the hand of his companion.

Beside the male is a gowned female who faces right. Her arms are raised at 135 degrees and one of her legs extends backward. She may be holding her companion's hand. Folds of drapery swirl behind her.
To the right of the group of figures following the text of line 14, two birds soar on extended wings.

lg.l: The head Sublime, the heart Pathos, the genitals Beauty,
the hands & feet Proportion.
As the air to a bird or the sea to a fish, so is contempt
to the contemptible.
The crow wish'd every thing was black, the owl, that eve-
-ry thing was white.
Exuberance is Beauty.
If the lion was advised by the fox. he would be cunning.
Improvent makes strait roads, but the crooked roads "Improvent": i.e., "Improvement."
without Improvement, are roads of Genius.
Sooner murder an infant in its cradle than nurse unact-
-ed desires
Where man is not nature is barren.
Truth can never be told so as to be understood, and
not be believ'd.
Enough! or Too much

illustration.illusobjdesc: Against a sky streaked with a rose-tinted dawn, (left to right) a human sun rises, a human tree trunk rises, and a maternal earth-goddess nurses an infant in a bed of vegetation. These identifications are tentative. The sun-goddess may be a flower-goddess; the personifications appear to change from Copy to copy. The scene is framed, below, by grassy ground on an island, peninsula, or shore, with water below. Above and on both sides, the scene is frame by the mouth of a cave. Green tinting suggests vegetation, perhaps moss or lichens. The cave finds a textual connection with the "narrow chinks" of a bodily "cavern" (Plate 13 in this copy, line 22). Perhaps we are to think of the cave formation here as the eye socket of the viewer. Thus, the viewer, not the figures pictured, is inside the cave, a perspective also suggested by the appearance of the sky in the distance.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene is framed, below, by grassy ground and water, and on the other three sides by the mouth of a cave. The latter finds a textual connection with the "narrow chinks" of a bodily "cavern" (plate 13, line 22). Perhaps we are to think of the cave formation here as the eye socket of the viewer. Thus, the viewer, not the figures pictured, is inside the cave, a perspective also suggested by the appearance of the sky in the distance.
The figures are placed on an island, peninsula, or shore, as indicated by the water (perhaps a river) below the land.
The green tinting of the ground below the figures suggests grass. Similar coloring of the cave's mouth, particularly left and top, hints at vegetation, perhaps moss or lichens.
A nude female is shown from the waist up. Her long hair, spiked and spread, and her arms, raised at 135 degrees, suggest that she personifies the rising sun.
The face of an old man with a long beard and spiky hair standing on end suggests a personification of the tree trunk in which he appears.
The face of an old, bearded man appears in the trunk or stump of a tree. In some copies, this motif would appear to be a water spout, colored blue and continued further toward the top of the plate.

Looking down at an infant, a female with long hair lies on her right side, her weight supported on her right elbow. There is a bit of drapery above her lower leg; she may be gowned or nude. Her back is to the viewer. Her right hand rests near the infant, perhaps touching it. She may personify the earth in which she seems partly buried. She may be the infant's mother.
A nude infant, arms raised and legs spread, faces up towards a nude female. It may represent the human form of the flower- like vegetation in which it lies.

A nude infant, arms raised and legs spread, faces up towards a nude female. It may represent the human form of the lush flame-like, flowery vegetation in which it lies. The blossom-like structure extends in an arc over the heads of the infant and the female. A vine with leaves is intertwined with the plant above the woman's head. Right of the infant is some more vegetation with leaves, and perhaps a flying creature.

Between the large vegetation and the cave's mouth, and above two branches of small vegetation, is a small form that may be a bit of detached vegetation or a flying creature, perhaps a small bird or a moth or butterfly.
The tinting of the sky suggests a sunrise or sunset with clouds.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the word "deities" (line 11), the head and outstretched arms of a bearded male have terrified a tiny human figure at the left who flees—or swims on dark waters—into the murky darkness.

component.illusobjdesc: Perhaps in response to the bearded figure on the right, a tiny nude human figure flees to the left into darkness or swims on dark waters.
Below the word "deities" (line 11), the head and outstretched arms of a bearded male appear against a cloud or white cliffs.
Below the word "deities" (line 11), the head and outstretched arms of a bearded male appear against a cloud or white cliffs (the white cliffs of Dover?) rising above he sea.
A tiny nude human figure flees to the left into darkness or swims on dark waters. There would appear to be waves on the right, lapping against what might be a shoreline.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the upper left corner of the text, a standing figure faces right. Nine birds grace the plate passim. Also prominent are vine-like and serpentine vegetative motifs: the most notable of these is a large green leaf attached to a looped tendril, stretching beyond the word "Priesthood" in line 12. A long vine or serpent hovers above the text of line 6. At the beginning of line 7, a small figure, perhaps a child, stands ensconced in the curved extension of the "A" in "And." Toward the bottom of the plate, following "things" in line 15, is a group of sundry figures, all but one of whom are huddled or kneeling on the ground. The figure(?) bracketing the group on the left may be an anthropomorphic tree stump. On the far right, a headless body walks left, holding a sword in its right hand. The green coloring right of this figure suggests vegetation of some sort. Blue tinting here and there in the text area suggests sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Blue tinting here and there in the text area suggests sky.
In the upper left corner of the text, immediately preceding the "The" of line 2, stands a gowned figure, facing right.
Nine birds grace the plate passim. The largest of these soars upward on extended wings following "percieve" in line 6.

Vegetative motifs adorn the text of the plate: banners or ribbons extend from the ascenders of letters, e.g., the "h" of "with" in line 4; the "b" of "abstract" in line 11; and the "h" of "length" in line 14. Looped vines grow from other letters: the "d" of "under" in line 8, for example. A variation on this design are the intertwined vines cascading from the "d" of "deity" at the end of line 8. Further down, a stalk—mostly bare but for a stray leaf or two—is rooted in the base of the "A" of "And" in the left margin of line 14. The large leaf attached to a looped vine following "Priesthood" in line 14 constitutes the plate's most visible vegetative design. A vine, possibly looped, dangles from the "d" of "reside" (line 16) and into the right margin. Hovering above "percieve" in line 6 is a vine and leaf combination that resembles the nearby vine or serpent stretching across the same line of text. Right of line 15, near the right margin, is a green patch suggesting grass.
A serpent with a single coil hovers above the text of line 6. It faces right, its mouth open.

In the left margin of line 7, a small figure, perhaps a child, stands ensconced in the curved extension of the "A" in "And." It faces right, one arm drawn back and raised at 135 degrees. The other arm extends forward as the figure apparently grasps part of the letter that supports it.

Toward the bottom of the plate, following "things" in line 15, is a group of sundry figures. The indistinct shape on the left that brackets the group may in fact be an anthropomorphic tree stump with small branches for arms.
A group of four(?) figures, each of whom is kneeling, crouching, or sitting, follows the anthropomorphic tree stump.
Two(?) figures, clad in robes or gowns, face right. The figure on the right sits with head bent.

Two huddled figures follow the first group of two. They appear to be squatting or crouching with their arms wrapped around their torsos and their heads bent. Alternatively, one might interpret their general posture as one of kneeling, heads resting on crossed arms.
To the right of the huddled figures, a headless, nude body walks left. It holds a sword, which points down, in its right hand. The left arm swings freely behind the figure's back.
The headless figure holds a sword, blade down, in its right hand.

lg.l: The ancient Poets animated all sensible objects
with Gods or Geniuses, calling them by the names and
adorning them with the properties of woods, rivers,
mountains, lakes, cities, nations, and whatever their
enlarged & numerous senses could percieve.
And particularly they studied the genius of each
city & country. placing it under its mental deity.
Till a system was formed, which some took ad-
vantage of & enslav'd the vulgar by attempting to
realize or abstract the mental deities from their
objects; thus began Priesthood.
Choosing forms of worship from poetic tales.
And at length they pronouncd that the Gods
had orderd such things.
Thus men forgot that All deities reside
in the human breast.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An eagle with outspread wings and head up holds in its talons a coiled, open-mouthed serpent with its tongue out. A small bird is visible to the left of eagle's head. The dark coloring of the cloud- shaped forms on three sides of the design strongly suggest the cave formation on Plate 11 in this copy. Blue washes suggest a background sky, thereby placing the viewer within the cave.

component.illusobjdesc: The dark coloring of the cloud-shaped forms on three sides of the design strongly suggest the cave formation on Plate 11 in this copy. Blue washes suggest a background sky, thereby placing the viewer within the cave.
An eagle with outspread wings, mouth perhaps slightly open, and head up holds in its talons a coiled, open-mouthed serpent with its tongue out.
An eagle holds in its talons a coiled, open-mouthed serpent with its tongue out. The serpent's tail is extravagantly long and suggests a spiral.
To the left of the large eagle's head is a small bird—or perhaps another eagle seen at a distance.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A male and female flank the plate's second line, "A Memorable Fancy." Vines grow from the letters, connecting figures with text. Following the word "generation" in line 5, a very long, loopy vine, suggestive of a spiral, extends to the right margin. At the beginning of line 6 is a hovering child or infant, facing right with arm extended to touch a triangular object. A serpentine line separates the word "stones" (line 11) from two figures—one standing, the other reclining—about a third of the way down the plate. To the right of "expanse" in line 19, a branch with spiky leaves stretches to and then curves slightly down the right margin. Other vegetative motifs adorn the plate: a detached leaf appears in the upper left corner, next to the male figure; a sprig precedes "I" in line 3, and another follows "cave" in line 8; a branch or leafy vine dangles right of lines 14-15; a leaf hangs from a serpentine vine to the right of and above the eagle's head in the major design. Yellow and rose washes throughout the text area suggest a sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Yellow and rose washes throughout the text area suggest a sunrise or sunset.
To the left of the plate's second line, "A Memorable Fancy," a male figure hovers with arms raised horizontally. One leg is drawn up and bent at the knee. The other leg extends leftward.

To the right of the inscription, "A Memorable Fancy" (line 2), a female figure hovers. One arm is raised horizontally; the other is raised and bent toward the head. The figure's legs are together and may be crossed.
The long, looped vines growing from the "F" and "y" of "Fancy" in line 2 intersect with the male and female figures.
Following the word "generation" in line 5, a very long, loopy vine, suggestive of a spiral, extends to the right margin.
At the beginning of line 6 is a hovering child or infant, facing right with arm extended to touch a triangular object.
Following the word "stones" in line 11, a wavy line seems to illustrate the "Viper" mentioned in line 9.
The wavy line following the word "stones" in line 11 may represent a serpentine vegetative motif.
Following the serpent right of line 11, a figure stands facing right, arm(s) extended horizontally.

Adjacent to the standing figure at the end of line 11, a reclining figure faces left. The figure extends at least one arm forward, mimicking the gesture of its companion. The figure's legs are obscured.
Following the word "expanse" in line 19, a branch with spiky leaves stretches to and then curves slightly down the right margin of the plate.

Leaf and vine motifs adorn the plate passim. A detached leaf floats to the left of the male figure near line 2. A small sprig of leaves grows next to the initial "I" in line 3. In the right margin five lines down, a thin stem or branch with buds and/or leaves follows the word "cave" (line 8). Continuing the vegetative motif, leaves grace a few delicate curves next to "cliffs" in line 15. A double- looped vine extends from the "T" of "There" in line 20. And a leaf to the right of the eagle's head hangs from a serpentine, looped vine that concludes line 22.

lg.l: I was in a Printing house in Hell & saw the
method in which knowledge is transmitted from gene-
-ration to generation.
In the first chamber was a Dragon-Man, clear-
-ing away the rubbish from a caves mouth; within, a
number of Dragons were hollowing the cave,
In the second chamber was a Viper folding round
the rock & the cave, and others adorning it with gold
silver and precious stones.
In the third chamber was an Eagle with wings
and feathers of air, he caused the inside of the cave
to be infinite, around were numbers of Eagle like
men, who built palaces in the immense cliffs.
In the fourth chamber were Lions of flaming fire
raging around & melting the metals into living fluids.
In the fifth chamber were Unnam'd forms, which
cast the metals into the expanse.
There they were reciev'd by Men who occupied
the sixth chamber, and took the forms of books &
were arranged in libraries.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A bluish male body, nude, arms at his sides, extends horizontally across the plate. The color and arrangement suggest that he is dead. Hovering in flames over him is a nude(?), long-haired female figure with her arms raised horizontally. She is at right angles to the male with her head toward the viewer. At least twice Blake color printed the plate, with its text masked (Butlin nos. 260.5, 261.3). His inscription for one of these, "a Flaming Sword / Revolving every way" (E673, K 261), relates the design to the so-called covering cherub, or guardian angel, whom God posted to keep humanity away from the Tree of Life after the expulsion from Eden. The top (rotating) figure in the design would then seem to be a personification of the sword-as-angel who is keeping the dead figure below away from the Tree of Life.
