Green coloring on the ground below the supine figure hints at grass; blue sky fills the background.

component.illusobjdesc: Green coloring on the ground below the supine figure hints at grass.
A bluish male body, nude, arms at his sides, extends horizontally across the plate. Color and arrangement suggest that he is dead. His hair appears to be curly.

Hovering in flames over the dead male is a nude(?), long- haired female figure with her arms raised horizontally. Her hair is long and drifts to the right in serpentine tendrils suggesting a spiral. She is at right angles to the male with her head toward the viewer. She may represent the so-called covering cherub, the angel whom God assigned to keep humanity away from the Tree of Life after the expulsion from Eden.
The female figure hovers in flames that lick up from behind the dead male below.
The background coloring suggests sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Assorted vegetative motifs follow the word "enjoyment" in line 11, approximately halfway down the plate. Consisting of mostly leaves, this pattern is interrupted by a small cluster of thistles or burrs. The final leaf in the series hangs from a stem growing from the "d" of "body" in line 12. Toward the bottom of the plate, a leaping horse is flanked by elaborate vegetative ascenders. Blue and yellow coloring throughout the text area suggests sky, possibly at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Blue and yellow coloring throughout the text area suggests sky, possibly at sunrise or sunset.

Midway down the plate, four or five leaves follow the word "enjoyment" in line 11. A small cluster of thistles or burrs appears between the third and fourth leaves. The final leaf grows from the ascender of "body" at the end of line 12.
Flanked by vegetative motifs, a leaping horse faces left near the bottom of the plate, following "finite" in line 20.

The leaping horse following "finite" in line 20 is flanked by elaborate vegetative ascenders: to the left, a long, single-looped vine grows from the "h" of "has" in line 21, and to the right, some serpentine, leafy grass(?) extends from the "d" of "closed." Various other vegetative motifs adorn letters passim, and a single leaf-like swirl curves above "is" at the end of line 5.

lg.l: The ancient tradition that the world will be con-
-sumed in fire at the end of six thousand years
is true. as I have heard from Hell.
For the cherub with his flaming sword is
hereby commanded to leave his guard at tree of
life, and when he does, the whole creation will
be consumed, and appear infinite. and holy
whereas it now appears finite & corrupt.
This will come to pass by an improvement of
sensual enjoyment.
But first the notion that man has a body
distinct from his soul, is to be expunged; this
I shall do, by printing in the infernal method, by
corrosives, which in Hell are salutary and me-
-dicinal, melting apparent surfaces away, and
displaying the infinite which was hid.
If the doors of perception were cleansed
every thing would appear to man as it is, in-
-finite.
For man has closed himself up, till he sees
all things thro' narrow chinks of his cavern.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Line 2, "A Memorable Fancy," is flanked by interlinear designs. The base of the letter "A" grows into a long, looped vine. Three swirls curve above the vegetation, and a small figure dances(?). Two birds fly above the text. To the right of the inscription, a monkey-like figure strides across a vine. Left of line 3, a (grape?) leaf introduces "The Prophets." The plate as a whole is rich with vegetative swirls and lines, which are often vine-like or serpentine, though those above "saw" in line 8 resonate with the image of outspread wings of soaring birds, such as those found above lines 7 and 9. Some of the vegetative motifs extend from ascenders and descenders of letters. Wedged between the right margin and the word "imposition" at the end of line 7 is a looping vine or possibly a worm. At the beginning of line 8, a snake with open mouth precedes the word "Isaiah." Hovering above text and among swirls, hovering figures appear at the ends of lines 15 and 19. Blue, rose, and yellow washes throughout the plate suggest sky, possibly at sunrise or sunset. There may be clouds in the lower left corner.

component.illusobjdesc: Blue, rose, and yellow washes throughout the plate suggest sky, possibly at sunrise or sunset.
There may be a bank of clouds in the lower left corner of the plate.
The base of the letter "A" in line 2, "A Memorable Fancy," grows into a long, looped vine, suggestive of a spiral. Line 3 is introduced by a (grape?) leaf.

A small figure dances(?), perhaps runs, above the looped vine growing from the letter "A" in line 2. Its arms are raised horizontally. One leg extends backward. The figure faces right and appears to be nude.
To the left of the dancing figure in the top left corner of the plate are three vegetative swirls, perhaps vine fragments or leaves.
Given the blue tinting in the area, the swirls in the top right corner of the plate might be clouds.

Following the word "Fancy" in line 2, a monkey-like, nude figure walks or strides left across a single-looped vine. Its right arm extends forward; the figure bends from the waist, somewhat hunched over. Its general posture recalls that of the blindfolded or bearded interlinear figure of plate 4.
The monkey-like figure to the right of line 2 walks or strides across a single-looped vine.

Five birds soar on extended wings: two fly above the plate's second line, "A Memorable Fancy"; one flies over the word "perswaded" in line 11; and a particularly small bird appears above "perception" in line 9. The largest of the birds has a wingspread the length of the word "cause" in line 7, over which it flies.

The plate is rich with vegetative designs—vines, swirls, banners, and ribbons—that are unattached or growing from letters: the "F" of "Fancy" in line 2 and the "T" of "Then" at the beginning of line 14 sport looped and/or vine-like growths, as do various ascenders, e.g., those of "and" in line 5 and "understood" in line 7. The descender of "prophesying" at the bottom of the plate is particularly long, elaborate, and snake-like. Free-floating lines, squiggles, and swirls are abundant: intertwined vines or tendrils occupy the right margin approximately halfway down the plate. The hovering figures following the text of lines 15 and 19 are flanked by such vegetative designs. Some of the smaller detached lines, such as those above "saw" in line 8, resemble wing fragments, i.e., they resonate with the image of outspread wings of soaring birds, such as those found above lines 7 and 11.
Wedged between the right margin and the word "imposition" at the end of line 7, a looped vine, or perhaps a worm, coincides with the second ascender of "heard" in the following line (line 8).
Facing right, a snake with open mouth precedes the word "Isaiah" in line 8.

Flanked by vegetative motifs, a figure hovers above the text of line 16. It faces left with arm(s) extended and its legs are spread apart. Drapery, or possibly at tail, extends to the right of the figure.
Facing right and up, a nude figure hovers at the end of line 19. Its arms are raised horizontally. Positioned together, the legs seem almost to fuse.

lg.l: The Prophets Isaiah and Ezekiel dined with
me, and I asked them how they dared so roundly to
assert. that God spoke to them; and whether they
did not think at the time, that they would be mis-
-understood, & so be the cause of imposition,
Isaiah answer'd. I saw no God, nor heard
any, in a finite organical perception; but my sen-
-ses discover'd the infinite in every thing, and as I
was then perswaded, & remain confirm'd; that the
voice of honest indignation is the voice of God, I
cared not for consequences but wrote.
Then I asked: does a firm perswasion that a
thing is so, make it so?
He replied, All poets believe that it does, &
in ages of imagination this firm perswasion remo
-ved mountains; but many are not capable of a
firm perswasion of any thing.
Then Ezekiel said. The philosophy of the east
taught the first principles of human perception
some nations held one principle for the origin &
some another, we of Israel taught that the Poetic
Genius (as you now call it) was the first principle
and all the others merely derivative, which was the
cause of our despising the Priests & Philosophers
of other countries, and prophecying that all Gods

illustration.illusobjdesc: Figures and vegetative motifs dominate the interlinear designs. At the top of the plate, two children dive toward the ascender of "be" in line 2. A figure clad in billowing garments hovers a third of the way down the plate in the right margin. Immediately below line 26, the prophet Ezekiel lies sideways on a long undulating vegetative bed. Vines, sometimes serpentine, and banners extend from letters. Detached leaves, swirls, vines, and other bits of vegetation are also prevalent, e.g., the leafy(?) vine following line 10 and the vines following the word "Grecian" at the end of line 20. Yellow, blue, and rose washes throughout the plate suggest sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Yellow, blue, and rose washes throughout the plate suggest sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

At the top of the plate, two children or infants dive toward the ascender of "be" in line 2. The child on the left faces right, descending at an angle. Its arms are extended, and its legs appear to be positioned together.
The child on the right faces left, its body nearly horizontal. Its arms are extended and its legs are apart.

A third of the way down the plate in the right margin, following "jews" in line 10, a figure faces left and down with arms extended. It appears to be clad in a billowing garment, whose folds might also be interpreted as wings. Perhaps this is the anthropomorphic form of an insect. The figure is nearly horizontal.

Immediately below line 26, a figure usually identified as Ezekiel lies sideways on a serpentine vegetative bed that stretches nearly the width of the plate. He is nude and faces away from the viewer. The design illustrates the text of lines 21 and 22: "I then asked Ezekiel why he . . . lay / so long on his right & left side?"
Ezekiel lies sideways on a long, undulating vegetative bed, serpentine or vine-like in appearance. The bed spans nearly the width of the plate.
Following the word "Grecian" at the end of line 20, two intertwined and serpentine vines stretch to the right margin of the plate.

Numerous other vegetative motifs adorn the plate. A curved line, leaf-like, coincides with the "l" of "would" in line 2; to the right, a banner waves from the ascender of "proved"; at the end of the same line of text, a three-looped vine extends from the "b" of "be." Two lines down (line 4), the "y" of "fervently" grows into a long, single- or double-looped vine; from the "e" of "we" at the end of line 6, an extremely squiggly, serpentine vine hangs down; a vine follows the figure at the end of line 10; and a detached leaf(?) introduces line 14.

lg.l: would at last be proved to originate in ours & to be the
tributaries of the Poetic Genius, it was this. that our
great poet King David desired so fervently & invokes
so patheticly, saying by this he conquers enemies &
governs kingdoms; and we so loved our God. that we
cursed in his name all the deities of surrounding
nations, and asserted that they had rebelled; from
these opinions the vulgar came to think that all nati-
-ons would at last be subject to the jews.
This said he, like all firm perswasions, is come to
pass, for all nations believe the jews code and wor-
-ship the jews god, and what greater subjection can be
I heard this with some wonder, & must confess
my own conviction. After dinner I ask'd Isaiah to fa-
-vour the world with his lost works, he said none of
equal value was lost. Ezekiel said the same of his.
I also asked Isaiah what made him go naked and
barefoot three years? he answerd, the same that made
our friend Diogenes the Grecian.
I then asked Ezekiel. why he eat dung, & lay so
long on his right & left side? he answerd, the desire
of raising other men into a perception of the infinite
this the North American tribes practise. & is he hon-
-est who resists his genius or conscience. only for
the sake of present ease or gratification?

illustration.illusobjdesc: The first lines on this plate—"The Giants who formed this world into its sensual existence and now seem to live in it in chains" (lines 2-4)—seem to describe the design, which depicts five gowned human figures sitting in severely contracted positions, all crowded into a dark stone chamber, prison, or cavern. A dark shadow cuts across the top right third of the enclosure. The heads of all except the bearded central figure, who looks out toward the viewer, are down and turned toward the center. Though the limbs of the figures are drawn tightly together as if chained, no chains are in evidence—in line with the sentiment of the text that the giants only "seem" (line 3) to live in chains.

component.illusobjdesc: Five seated figures sit in a chamber, prison, or cave, probably built or cut from stone. In this copy, the walls look man- made, and thus more probably a prison or chamber than a cave. The leftmost section of the wall may be cracked or broken. A dark shadow cuts across the top right third of the enclosure.

The gowned figure on the far left sits against a wall, facing toward the center, in a severely contracted position with the visible leg drawn up and head down. The figure probably represents one of the "Giants who formed the world into its sensual existence" (lines 2-3).

The gowned figure second from the left sits with back against the wall in a severely contracted position with legs drawn up and crossed just above the ankle, head down but twisted toward the center, and right foot exposed. He is one of only two figures with face visible, seen in profile. His hair may be curly. The figure probably represents one of the "Giants who formed the world into its sensual existence" (lines 2-3).

The gowned male figure in the center, old and at least partly bald, sits with his back against the wall in a severely contracted position, legs drawn up and crossed, right foot exposed. His arms are raised horizontally to embrace the two figures at his side, right and left. The fingers of both hands are spread apart. The figure probably represents one of the "Giants who formed the world into its sensual existence" (lines 2-3). The design, however, closely resembles Blake's several illustrations of the Ugolino episode in Dante's *Divine Comedy*, and thus this central figure is compositionally related to (albeit not directly identifiable as) Count Ugolino surrounded by his sons in prison.

The gowned figure fourth from the left sits with his right side against the wall, facing the center in a severely contracted position with his one visible leg drawn up and his head down. His hair appears to be curly. The figure probably represents one of the "Giants who formed the world into its sensual existence" (lines 2-3).

The gowned figure on the right sits with his back against the wall far right, facing the center in a severely contracted position with his one visible leg drawn up and his head down. The figure probably represents one of the "Giants who formed the world into its sensual existence" (lines 2-3).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The interlinear designs are concentrated on the lower half of the plate: a figure sits poised at one end of a long, loopy vine following the word "whole" in line 14. Three lines (line 17) down are two small buds or flowers nestled between feathery leaves. Near the bottom of the plate, two figures, facing each other, hover amidst vegetative motifs and wispy lines suggestive of cirrus-like clouds. Serpentine ribbons in the right margin are the most conspicuous interlinear ornaments on the top half of the plate. Blue and yellow washes in the text area suggest sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Blue and yellow washes in the text area suggest sky.

Following the word "whole" in line 13, a small figure sits poised at one end of a long, loopy vine. The figure faces forward, its legs together and slightly extended. Its arms are raised horizontally.
Following the word "whole" in line 13, a figure sits poised at one end of a long, triple-looped, serpentine vine.
Next to "delights" in line 16, two small buds or flowers are nestled between feathery leaves of a small plant.

A figure hovers above "classes" in line 20 toward the bottom of the plate. Facing right, it extends its arm or arms, as though reaching toward a second figure from whom it is separated by some curved lines suggestive of cirrus-like clouds. The figure's body is nearly horizontal and its legs are slightly apart.

Hovering above "always" in line 20, a figure faces left. Its arm(s) extended, the figure seems to be reaching toward its companion from whom it is separated by some curved lines suggestive of cirrus-like clouds. The figure's legs are apart.
Following "Men" in line 19, the curved lines flanked by two figures, as well as the three stacked swirls to the right of the figures, may represent cirrus-like clouds.

At the end of line 19, the curved lines flanked by two figures, as well as the three stacked swirls to the right of the figures, resemble leaves or other stylized vegetative motifs. To the left of the first figure appears a vine or branch, possibly with spiky leaves, or simply a large spiky leaf.

Various other vegetative motifs adorn the plate passim: serpentine vines or ribbons cling to the right margin on the upper half of the plate. The first of these extends above the "h" of "which" in line 6. The "T" of "Thus" that opens line 9 has a looped, vine-like flourish. A vine twists between the right margin of the plate and the ends of lines 8-9.

lg.l: The Giants who formed this world into its
sensual existence and now seem to live in it
in chains, are in truth. the causes of its life
& the sources of all activity, but the chains
are, the cunning of weak and tame minds. which
have power to resist energy, according to the pro-
-verb, the weak in courage is strong in cunning.
Thus one portion of being, is the Prolific, the
other, the Devouring; to the devourer it seems as
if the producer was in his chains, but it is not so,
he only takes portions of existence and fancies
that the whole.
But the Prolific would cease to be Prolific
unless the Devourer as a sea recieved the excess
of his delights.
Some will say, Is not God alone the Prolific?
I answer, God only Acts & Is. in existing beings
or Men.
These two classes of men are always upon
earth. & they should be enemies; whoever tries

illustration.illusobjdesc: The balance of the interlinear designs are concentrated at the top half of the plate. Yellow, rose, and blue washes suggest sky, possibly at sunrise or sunset. In the top right corner, a pine tree is visible. Line 7 is teeming with animal life: a grazing sheep, a goat(?) walking on its hind legs, and two horses follow the word "Sword" and appear against a landscape of gently sloping hills and plains. A third of the way down the plate, birds fly to the right of and above the inscription, "A Memorable Fancy" (line 11). To the left a small figure stands under a willow with a body of water, perhaps the sea, in the background. Various letters take on a vegetative appearance, e.g., the "N" of "Note" in line 4 and the "d" of "twisted" in line 31, from which grows a squiggly root. Preceding the words "I said" in line 16, a barely discernible figure climbs among some spidery roots.

component.illusobjdesc: Yellow, rose, and blue washes suggest sky, possibly at sunrise or sunset.
A pine tree grows in the top right corner. Only the left outline of its trunk is pictured.

Line 7 is teeming with animal life: four mammals follow the word "Sword" and appear against a landscape of plains and gently sloping hills. Leading the procession, a grazing sheep(?) seemingly illustrates the reference in lines 5 and 6 to the biblical parable of sheep and goats.

Following the grazing sheep next to "Sword" in line 7, a goat(?) walks left on its hind legs. The goat's forelegs are extended in front of it. The pairing of the animal emblems illustrates the reference in lines 5 and 6 to the biblical parable of the sheep and goats.
To the right of the goat(?) below "came" in line 6, a horse walks left.
Following the staid horse below "to send" in line 6, a leaping or galloping horse faces left.
The small peaks and valleys constituting the landscape of the animal vignette are suggestive of plains and gently sloping hills.

Facing right and up, an eagle soars on extended wings above the inscription, "A Memorable Fancy" (line 11), which appears about a third of the way down the plate. To the right of the words, five more birds fly; the most prominent of these appears to be ascending.
To the right of the inscription, "A Memorable Fancy" (line 11), reeds or tufts of grass (?) form part of the backdrop against which the flock of birds flies.
To the left of the inscription, "A Memorable Fancy" (line 11), a small figure stands beneath a willow tree and gazes into the distance. The figure appears to hold a cane or walking-stick.
To the left of the inscription, "A Memorable Fancy" (line 11), a small figure stands under a willow tree.
The figure and tree left of "A Memorable Fancy" (line 11) stand before a body of water, possibly the sea.

Preceding the words "I said" in line 16, a barely discernible figure(?), facing right, climbs among some spidery roots, thus illustrating text in line 24 that describes the angel and the first person narrator suspended in the "roots of trees."

Preceding the words "I said" in line 16, a barely discernible figure(?), facing right, climbs among some spidery roots, thus illustrating text in line 24 that describes the angel and the narrator suspended in the "roots of trees."

Various vegetative motifs adorn the plate. A "twisted root" extends from the ascender of the first word in the phrase at the ends of lines 31 and 32. The "N" of "Note" at the beginning of line 4 grows into a single-looped vine.

lg.l: to reconcile them seeks to destroy existence,
Religion is an endeavour to reconcile the two.
Note. Jesus Christ did not wish to unite
but to seperate them, as in the Parable of sheep and
goats! & he says I came not to send Peace but a
Sword.
Messiah or Satan or Tempter was formerly
thought to be one of the Antediluvians who are our
Energies
An Angel came to me and said O pitiable foolish
young man! O horrible! O dreadful state! consider
the hot burning dungeon thou art preparing for thyself
to all eternity, to which thou art going in such career.
I said. perhaps you will be willing to shew me
my eternal lot & we will contemplate together upon it
and see whether your lot or mine is most desirable
So he took me thro' a stable & thro' a church
& down into the church vault at the end of which
was a mill; thro' the mill we went, and came to a
cave. down the winding cavern we groped our tedi-
-ous way till a void boundless as a nether sky ap-
-peard beneath us, & we held by the roots of trees
and hung over this immensity, but I said, if you
please we will commit ourselves to this void, and
see whether providence is here also, if you will not
I will? but he answerd, do not presume O young-
man but as we here remain behold thy lot which
will soon appear when the darkness passes away
So I remaind with him sitting in the twisted

illustration.illusobjdesc: The plate is notable for the sparseness of its designs. Blue, rose, and yellow washes suggest sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset. Vegetative motifs are confined to the right margin: thread-thin stems with three scanty leaves each hang from "deep," "vast," and "deep" again, the final words in lines 3, 7, and 16, respectively; an angular stem and bud(?) combination curves above "sea" in line 27.

component.illusobjdesc: Blue, rose, and yellow washes suggest sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

Vegetative motifs are confined to the right margin: thread-thin stems with three scanty leaves apiece hang from "deep," "vast," and "deep" again, the final words in lines 3, 7, and 16, respectively; an angular stem and bud(?) combination curves above "sea" in line 27.

lg.l: root of an oak. he was suspended in a fungus
which hung with the head downward into the deep;
By degrees we beheld the infinite Abyss, fiery
as the smoke of a burning city; beneath us at an
immense distance was the sun, black but shining
round it were fiery tracks on which revolv'd vast
spiders, crawling after their prey; which flew or
rather swum in the infinite deep, in the most ter-
-rific shapes of animals sprung from corruption.
& the air was full of them, & seemd composed
of them; these are Devils. and are called Powers
of the air, I now asked my companion which was my
eternal lot? he said, between the black & white spiders
But now, from between the black & white spiders
a cloud and fire burst and rolled thro the deep
blackning all beneath, so that the nether deep grew
black as a sea & rolled with a terrible noise: be-
-neath us was nothing now to be seen but a black
tempest, till looking east between the clouds & the
waves. we saw a cataract of blood mixed with fire
and not many stones throw from us appeard and
sunk again the scaly fold of a monstrous serpent
at last to the east, distant about three degrees ap-
-peard a fiery crest above the waves slowly it rear
-ed like a ridge of golden rocks till we discoverd
two globes of crimson fire. from which the sea
fled away in clouds of smoke, and now we saw, it
was the head of Leviathan, his forehead was di
-vided into streaks of green & purple like those on
a tygers forehead: soon we saw his mouth & red
gills hang just above the raging foam tinging the
black deep with beams of blood, advancing toward

illustration.illusobjdesc: Blue, rose, and yellow washes suggest sky throughout the plate, possibly at sunrise or sunset. Following the word "mind" in line 10, a pair of figures hovers amidst sky and clouds; a two(?) birds complete the vignette. A single-looped, serpentine vine seemingly points toward two more birds three lines down. Left of line 14, a small figure runs in the general direction of "I answerd." Near the bottom of the plate, two hovering figures touch hands. They are followed by a soaring bird, which is overshadowed by the reappearance of the hybrid serpent/bird found on Plate 5. Various vegetative motifs adorn the plate passim, e.g., the vine-like descender of "My" in line 3. Several of these motifs line the right margin.

component.illusobjdesc: An interlinear vignette follows "mind" in line 10: two figures, facing right and down, with arms extended, descend through or hover in the air amidst clouds, sky, and at least one bird. The male(?) figure, positioned slightly below the female(?), flies with legs apart.
A bank of clouds appears to the right of the pair of figures at the end of line 10.
Blue, yellow, and rose washes suggest sky throughout the plate, possibly at a sunrise or sunset.
Following the pair of figures next to "mind" in line 10, a bird soars on extended wings amidst sky and clouds. Further to the right may be a smaller bird, turned sideways in mid- flight.
A serpentine, single-looped vine, which seemingly terminates in a leaf, follows "escaped?" in line 13.
Next to the squiggly vine at the end of line 13, two birds soar on extended wings.

Facing right and down, a small figure, perhaps a child, runs toward the text of line 14. Its arms are raised nearly horizontally. A tiny protrusion extends from its back (although, in this copy, it may only be his other arm).

Two hovering figures, perhaps a male and female, follow "stars" in line 27. They face each other and hold hands, reaching across a wing-like motif, shadow, or vegetable form. The figure on the left is nearly horizontal. On the right, the second figure extends one bent leg backward.

Directly beneath the two figures who follow "stars" in line 27 is a wavy, detached vegetable object(?). Like some of the vegetative fragments on Plate 14, this one resonates with the image of outspread wings of soaring birds, such as those found to the right of the figures.
A small bird flies to the right of the hand-holding figures at the end of line 27.

The small soaring bird is overshadowed by the marvelous hybrid serpent/bird to its right. The creature displays pseudo-batwings and, like its analogue on Plate 5, is dragon-like in appearance. The looped and squiggly extension of the animal may be a snaky tail. Alternatively, it could represent a serpent dangling from the talons of the bird, hearkening back to the major design of Plate 12, which depicts an eagle gripping a coiled serpent in its talons.

Several vegetative motifs, mostly appearing in the form of letter extensions, adorn the plate: the most notable of these are the single-looped vine growing from the descender of "My" in line 3 and the serpentine "y" of "westerly" in line 19. The right margin bears traces of other such motifs, especially the vine and leaf(?) associated with the ampersand at the end of line 11. The wing-like form below the figures following line 27 may be a vine.

lg.l: us with all the fury of a spiritual existence.
My friend the Angel climb'd up from his sta-
-tion into the mill; I remain'd alone, & then this
appearance was no more, but I found myself sit- In Copy G, the "e" in "myself" is very faint.
-ting on a pleasant bank beside a river by moon
light hearing a harper who sung to the harp. &
his theme was, The man who never alters his
opinion is like standing water, & breeds reptiles
of the mind.
But I arose, and sought for the mill &
there I found my Angel, who surprised asked
me, how I escaped?
I answerd. All that we saw was owing to your
metaphysics; for when you ran away, I found myself
on a bank by moonlight hearing a harper, But
now we have seen my eternal lot, shall I shew you
yours? he laughd at my proposal; but I by force
suddenly caught him in my arms, & flew westerly
thro' the night, till we were elevated above the
earths shadow: then I flung myself with him direct-
-ly into the body of the sun, here I clothed myself in
white, & taking in my hand Swedenborgs volumes
sunk from the glorious clime, and passed all the
planets till we came to saturn, here I staid to rest
& then leap'd into the void, between saturn & the
fixed stars.
Here said I! is your lot, in this space, if space
it may be calld, Soon we saw the stable and the
church, & I took him to the altar and open'd the
Bible, and lo! it was a deep pit, into which I de-
-scended driving the Angel before me, soon we saw
seven houses of brick, one we enterd; in it were a

objnote.p: At the bottom of the plate, in the waves under the leviathan, Blake etched in white line: "Opposition is True Friendship." Color printing obscured this line completely in Copies E and F, and watercolor finishing made it barely visible in the other colored copies, A, C, D, G-I. In uncolored Copy B, "Friendship" was filled in with ink and did not print legibly.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the waves of a dark and tumultuous sea, Leviathan appears as a coiled, scaly serpent with its head raised vertically, mouth open, teeth visible, tongue extended. The background coloring of the sky above Leviathan suggests a sunrise or sunset with clouds. A particularly dark cloud hovers above the sea far left. Blake inscribed one of the two color-printed impressions of the design "O revolving serpent / O the Ocean of Time & Space" (see Butlin no. 260.6 for an uninscribed impression).

component.illusobjdesc: In the waves of a dark and tumultuous sea, Leviathan appears as a coiled, scaly serpent with its head raised vertically, its mouth open and teeth visible.

In the waves of a dark and tumultuous sea, Leviathan appears. The background coloring of the sky above Leviathan suggests a sunrise or sunset with clouds. Blake inscribed one of the two color- printed impressions of the design "O revolving serpent / O the Ocean of Time & Space" (see Butlin no. 260.6 for an uninscribed impression).
A particularly dark cloud hovers above the sea on the left.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The interlinear designs are relatively sparse. A serpentine line, partly obscured in this copy, follows line 20. Further to the right, a tiny figure sits on a branch extending from the right margin. Three monkey-like figures appear next to "Analytics" in line 15. They illustrate the perverse "monkeys, baboons, & all of that species" cited at the top of the plate and described more extensively in subsequent lines. Blue and yellow washes throughout the text area suggest sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Above Leviathan to the far right, on a branch extending from the right margin, sits a tiny figure. One leg appears to be dangling downward. The figure may be holding the branch with its left hand.
A serpentine curve, possibly a vine, follows "Analytics" in line 20. The motif is partly obscured by coloring in this copy.
A group of three monkey-like figures following "Analytics" in line 15 illustrates the perverse "monkeys, baboons, & all of that species" cited at the top of the plate.

The monkey-like figure immediately following "Analytics" stands facing left on the tiny ledge provided by the ascender of "has" in the subsequent line of text. The creature has no tail, in accord with the monkeys who have eaten their own tails, lines 11 and 12).

The middle figure, slightly more anthropomorphic than its companions, sits cross-legged. Looking right, it points at or gropes in the direction of the hunched-over shape near the margin, a gesture that perhaps visually signifies the "snatching" and jeering described in lines 3 and 4. Its other hand rests on the ground.
The more amorphous shape on the far right squats on its haunches, facing left. Its body and shoulders are hunched over.
Blue and yellow washes suggest sky throughout the text area.

lg.l: number of monkeys. baboons, & all of that species
chaind by the middle, grinning and snatching at
one another, but witheld by the shortness of their
chains; however I saw that they sometimes grew nu
merous, and then the weak were caught by the strong
and with a grinning aspect, first coupled with & then
devourd, by plucking off first one limb and then ano-
ther till the body was left a helpless trunk. this after
grinning & kissing it with seeming fondness they de-
vourd too; and here & there I saw one savourily pic-
king the flesh off of his own tail; as the stench ter
-ribly annoyd us both we went into the mill, & I in
my hand brought the skeleton of a body, which in
the mill was Aristotles Analytics.
So the Angel said: thy phantasy has imposed
upon me & thou oughtest to be ashamed.
I answerd! we impose on one another, & it is
but lost time to converse with you whose works
are only Analytics.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A curly-haired and youthful nude male with his head up to the right sits on a grassy hilltop or mound, possibly a grave mound. His right hand (and presumably his left, behind his back) rests on the ground to support the weight of his upper body. His feet—the right foot more prominent and forward—are drawn up toward his groin and his legs are spread wide apart, genitals exposed. His left knee rests on a human skull. A subtle radiance with beams of light extend from behind his lower body and radiate into the sky. The sun may be rising behind him.

component.illusobjdesc: A curly-haired and youthful nude male with his head up to the right sits on a grassy hilltop or mound. His right hand (and presumably his left, behind his back) rests on the ground to support the weight of his upper body. His feet—the right foot more prominent and forward—are drawn up toward his groin and his legs are spread wide apart, genitals exposed. His left knee rests on a human skull.
The figure's left knee rests on a human skull.
The nude male sits on a grassy hilltop or mound. The presence of the skull suggests that this may be a grave mound.
Green tinting suggests grass below the figure.
A subtle radiance with beams of light extend from behind the man's lower body and radiate into the sky. The sun may be rising behind him.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The smaller figures, interspersed among various vegetative designs, all appear immediately above the first line of text: at the far left, a gowned (and winged?) female(?) reaches her arms out to a small child who leans slightly toward her. The female rests against a grain tassel. Following a combination of stylized leaves and a three-looped vine, a child and adult face each other, the former lying with head raised, the latter kneeling with hands on ground or holding the child's hand. To their right, the final figure sits reading on a vegetable surface. A leaf-like extension arches above the figure. An elaborate sequence of snake-like, looped vines and serpentine motifs follow "reasoning" in line 5. The designs, which conclude with a branch bearing spiky leaves, stretch to the right margin of the plate. Another such sequence occurs right of line 8, where large leaves and other vegetative motifs follow the two words of text, "publish'd books." A small plant with leaves immediately precedes the catchword "one" (line 15). Blue tinting in the text area suggests sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Directly above "I have" in line 2, a gowned female reaches her arms out to a small child who leans slightly toward her. The child faces right, standing on a leaf.

Directly above "I have" in line 2, a gowned, winged female(?) reaches her arms out to a small child. Resting against or sitting at the base of a grain tassel, she faces left and bends forward from the waist as though preparing to lift the child.

The gowned woman above "I have" in line 2 rests against the stem of a grain tassel. The child she clasps stands on a leaf or frond, one of three that curve around the "I" in line 2. To the right of the woman, the grain or leaf stem grows into two scanty leaves or branches. Continuing the mixed vegetative motif, a triple-looped, serpentine vine—suggestive of a spiral—extends from the leaves toward the next pair of figures.

Above "that Angels" in line 2, a child and an adult face each other. The child lies on a vegetative slope. It faces right with head raised. The child has at least one arm extended toward the adult and may be holding the adult's hand.

Above "that Angels" in line 2, a child and an adult face each other. The adult faces left and down, perhaps looking at the child. The figure appears to be either kneeling with hands on ground or holding the child's hand.
Beneath the child and female and above "that Angels" in line 2, a wavy, serpentine line represents a vegetative surface, perhaps a continuation of the vine motif on the left.

On the far right of the plate and above line 2, the final figure in the series sits reading on a vegetative surface, perhaps a leaf. The figure faces right, a book propped on its knees. Over the figure arches a leaf.
On the far right of the plate and above line 2, a figure sits reading on a leaf or frond; a leaf-like canopy arches over the figure.

An elaborate sequence of snake-like, looped vines and serpentine motifs follow "reasoning" in line 5. The designs, which conclude with a branch bearing spiky leaves, stretch to the right margin of the plate. A similar sequence occurs right of line 8, where two or three large, sinuous leaves, followed by two narrow vines or leaves, predominate over the two words of text, "publish'd books."

A vine-like loop, shaped like a bird with neck and head twisted to the right, precedes line 9, the first letter of which bears a vine-like extension. Leaves(?) precede line 6. The catchword is preceded by a small plant or tree with leaves.
The form preceding line 9 might be vegetation, but it takes the form of a bird with its head and neck twisted to the right.
Blue tinting in the text area suggests sky.

lg.l: I have always found that Angels have the vani-
-ty to speak of themselves as the only wise; this they
do with a confident insolence sprouting from systema-
-tic reasoning;
Thus Swedenborg boasts that what he writes is
new; tho' it is only the Contents or Index of already
publish'd books
A man carried a monkey about for a shew, & be-
-cause he was a little wiser than the monkey, grew
vain, and conciev'd himself as much wiser than se-
-ven men. It is so with Swedenborg; he shews the
folly of churches & exposes hypocrites, till he im-
-agines that all are religious. & himself the single

illustration.illusobjdesc: Blue and yellow washes throughout the plate suggest sky. At the end of line 2, a scrolled shape with wavy lines intersecting its midsection has been seen as a sea creature entangled in the remnants of a net; the scene as a whole is said to illustrate the text that continues from the previous plate, which describes Swedenborg's self- deceptions: he imagines "himself the single / one on earth that ever broke a net" (Plate 21, lines 14-15; Plate 22, line 2). In this copy, the shape seems vegetative or worm-like. Beyond this shape, a hunched figure (possibly holding a book or tablet) sits on a vine. Following "falshoods" in line 5, a figure clad in a billowing garment hovers amidst some vegetation. Below, two elaborate spirals radiate from a common center right of line 9. To the right of "further" in line 12 are several large, vivid leaves. Next to "number" in line 17, three birds soar on extended wings. To the left of the long-tailed bird and below the small, nondescript bird are two swollen vegetable forms. A loop extending above the "h" of "he" at the end of line 18 coincides with the wing of the largest bird. Four figures bound the plate's inscription, "A Memorable Fancy" (line 21), on three sides. The first figure reclines beneath some leaves and branches to the left of the text. The vegetation transforms into loops and squiggles clinging to the margin of the plate. Above the inscription (line 21), a hovering figure, arm(s) extended, seems to reach for a serpent. The four-looped vine growing from the "F" of "Fancy" and the squiggly "y" of the same word continue the serpentine motif. To the right of the text, the third figure of the vignette stands facing right with arms raised at 135 degrees. His head is bent back, and his posture suggests he has just been impaled by the invisible arrow released from the bow of the fourth figure, who leaps through the air brandishing the weapon. Behind him, a snake or vine coils around a tall tuft of grass. Further down, a flower with leaves and/or thorns adorns the space following "words" in line 24. Right of the flower is an oddly-shaped vine, or perhaps a flying bird or insect appears to carry a snake through the air, recalling similar motifs on Plates 5, 15, and 19. Vegetable forms follow, with another large leaf or vine extending horizontally below line 26, lower left. Ornamenting the left margin are various other small-scale vegetative designs attached to letters.

component.illusobjdesc: Blue and yellow washes throughout the plate suggest sky.

At the end of line 2, a scrolled, serpentine shape with wavy lines intersecting its midsection is sometimes seen as a sea creature entangled in the remnants of a net; the scene as a whole is said to illustrate the text that continues from the previous plate, which describes Swedenborg's self-deceptions: he imagines "himself the single / one on earth that ever broke a net" (Plate 21, lines 14-15; Plate 22, line 2). In this copy, the form seems vegetative or worm-like.

At the end of line 2 near the right margin, a small figure sits with hunched shoulders on a vine. The figure faces left. It seems to hold an indeterminate object, perhaps a book or tablet. Thus, the figure may be reading or writing.
Various swirls and lines crossing at the end of line 2 suggest vines.

Following "falshoods" in line 5 is a hovering figure swathed in billowing garments. The swirls and folds of the garment appear vegetative in nature. The figure appears to be facing left and down, with one arm extended and perhaps pointing to the left.

Following "falshoods" in line 5 is a figure swathed in billowing garments. The swirls and folds of the garment appear vegetative in nature, and the figure is flanked by a small leaf- bearing branch on the left and flat, stylized leaves or ribbons on the right.

Following "notions" in line 9, two long, loopy vines—cf. a similar interlinear motif on Plate 14—radiate from a common center. The first four loops in the spiral on the right reverse the direction of those on the left.
Three leaves, the first of which is particularly vivid and broad, appear to the right of "further" in line 12.
Following "number" in line 17, three birds soar on extended wings. The bird on the far left has a particularly long, forked tail.

To the left of the long-tailed bird and below the smaller, nondescript bird at the end of line 17 are two swollen vegetable forms. A vine-like loop extending above the "h" of "he" at the end of line 18 coincides with the wing of the largest bird.

Four figures bound the plate's inscription, "A Memorable Fancy," on three sides in line 21. The first figure reclines beneath some leaves and branches to the left of the text. Like Ezekiel in plate 15, this figure lies on its side, but—unlike the prophet—it faces the viewer with head resting on hand.

The first of four figures that ornament the space around the plate's inscription reclines beneath some leaves and branches to the left of the text. The vegetative canopy arches over the figure. The slope on which it lies is vine-like, becoming snaky—i.e., loopy and serpentine—as it clings to and climbs the left margin.

Above the inscription, "A Memorable Fancy," in line 21, the second figure hovers, facing right. Its legs are apart; one of them is extended backward and bent slightly at the knee. The figure's body is horizontal. Arm(s) outstretched, it seems to reach for the squiggly snake in front of it.
The hovering figure above the plate's inscription, "A Memorable Fancy," in line 21 seems to reach for the squiggly serpent in front of it. The serpent faces right; its mouth is open.

To the right of the plate's inscription, "A Memorable Fancy" (line 21), a nude male stands facing right with arms raised at 135 degrees. His hands are turned with palms facing up. The figure's head is bent back, and his legs are together; leaning backward, he appears to have just been impaled by the invisible arrow released from the bow of the fourth figure.

Facing the third figure who stands leaning slightly backward to the right of the plate's inscription, a nude figure leaps through the air brandishing a bow in its right arm. The left arm is drawn back. One leg is bent at the knee and extended backward.

The four-looped, spiraling vine growing from the "F" of "Fancy" in line 21 and the squiggly "y" of the same word continue the serpentine motif of the plate and the vignette. Behind the nude figure who leaps through the air brandishing a bow, a snake(?) or vine coils around a tall tuft of grass near the right margin of the plate.
Near the right margin of the plate and following the inscription, "A Memorable Fancy," in line 21, the form coiled around a tall tuft of grass might be a snake.
A flower with leaves and/or thorns adorns the space following "words" in line 24. Further to the right is an oddly-shaped vine, or perhaps a flying insect or bird holding a snake.

Next to the flower at the end of line 24, the oddly-shaped vine might be a bird or an insect flying on extended wings with a serpent or snake-like vegetation attached to it. The creature appears to be facing up. The motif recalls similar hybrids on Plates 5, 15, and 19.

Next to the flower at the end of line 24, what might be a bird or an insect flies on extended wings with a serpent or serpentine vegetation attached to it. Two more vegetable forms follow; the second resembles a flaccid, swollen snake.
A large vine extends horizontally beneath line 26.

Ornamenting the left margin of the plate are various small-scale vegetative motifs, most of which are closely associated with letters, e.g., the leafy flourish off the "N" of "Now" in line 3 and the serpentine vines growing next to the "A" of "And" in line 6 and the "H" of "Have" in line 13. Vines or small leaves appear left of the first letters of the first words in lines 10 and 18.

lg.l: one on earth that ever broke a net.
Now hear a plain fact: Swedenborg has not writ-
-ten one new truth: Now hear another: he has written
all the old falshoods.
And now hear the reason. He conversed with Angels
who are all religious. & conversed not with Devils who
all hate religion, for he was incapable thro' his conceited
notions.
Thus Swedenborgs writings are a recapitulation of
all superficial opinions, and an analysis of the more
sublime. but no further.
Have now another plain fact: Any man of mechani
-cal talents may from the writings of Paracelsus or Ja
-cob Behmen, produce ten thousand volumes of equal
value with Swedenborg's. and from those of Dante or
Shakespear, an infinite number.
But when he has done this, let him not say that he
knows better than his master, for he only holds a can-
-dle in sunshine.
Once I saw a Devil in a flame of fire, who arose be
fore an Angel that sat on a cloud. and the Devil ut-
terd these words.
The worship of God is. Honouring his gifts in other
men each according to his genius. and loving the

illustration.illusobjdesc: Blue, rose, and yellow washes throughout the plate suggest sky, possibly at sunrise or sunset. The printing and coloring of the etching border at the top, with sky below, recalls the cave form on Plate 11. Sundry figure and animal motifs appear below the text: in the lower left corner of the plate, the oddly-shaped form may be a snake with a gaping mouth(?) facing left (more clearly so in other copies). Next to it is what appears to be an upside-down human figure or animal. Continuing the sequence, a hovering figure facing down is followed by another snake or serpentine vine. A final figure also lies on its side, but—as with the interlinear Ezekiel in Plate 15—the viewer sees it from behind. Various vegetative motifs adorn the left and especially the right margin, e.g., the serpentine vine following "replied" in line 6.

component.illusobjdesc: Blue, rose, and yellow washes throughout the plate suggest sky, possibly at sunrise or sunset.
The printing and coloring of the etching border at the top, with sky below, recalls the cave form on Plate 11.
In the bottom left corner of the plate, the odd form may be a snake with an enormous, gaping mouth(?) facing left (more clearly so in other copies).

In other copies, the second motif from the left at the bottom of the plate clearly depicts a figure on hands and knees, not unlike the bearded Nebuchadnezzar in the major design of Plate 24, except that the interlinear version is upside-down. In Copy G, however, the form may be either a falling human figure, arms and one leg raised upward, or an animal.

At the bottom of the plate, the third design from the left depicts a figure facing down, its body slightly curved and perhaps falling. One or both arms are raised vertically (in relation to the figure's head); the figure appears to rest its head in the crook of its arm. Its legs are together.
At the bottom of the plate, a serpentine vine or snake is flanked by two human figures.
At the bottom of the plate, a serpentine vine or snake is flanked by two human figures.

Following the snake at the bottom of the plate, the last figure of the series lies on its side. Like Ezekiel on Plate 15, this figure is seen from behind. One leg is extended; the other is drawn up and bent at the knee. The nude figure rests its head on one arm, which is bent at the elbow.

Various vegetative motifs adorn the left and especially the right margin, e.g., the snaky vine following "replied" in line 5; the vine-like squiggles following "he" in line 14; and the serpentine shape next to "virtue" in line 24.

lg.l: greatest men best, those who envy or calumniate
great men hate God, for there is no other God.
The Angel hearing this became almost blue
but mastering himself he grew yellow, & at last
white pink & smiling. and then replied,
Thou Idolater, is not God One? & is not he
visible in Jesus Christ? and has not Jesus Christ
given his sanction to the law of ten commandments
and are not all other men fools, sinners & nothings?
The Devil answer'd; bray a fool in a morter with
wheat yet shall not his folly be beaten out of him:
if Jesus Christ is the greatest man, you ought to
love him in the greatest degree; now hear how he
has given his sanction to the law of ten command-
-ments: did he not mock at the sabbath, and so
mock the sabbaths God? murder those who were
murderd because of him? turn away the law from
the woman taken in adultery? steal the labor of
others to support him? bear false witness when
he omitted making a defence before Pilate? covet
when he pray'd for his disciples, and when he bid
them shake off the dust of their feet against such
as refused to lodge them? I tell you, no virtue
can exist without breaking these ten command-
-ments; Jesus was all virtue, and acted from im-

illustration.illusobjdesc: A bearded nude male, looking out at the viewer with an expression of apprehension and dismay, crawls on hands and knees against a background that suggests gigantic tree trunks on the floor of a forest. The points of a crown can be seen on his head. This is apparently Nebuchadnezzar (not mentioned in the text), king of Babylon, enslaver of the Israelites, whose fall and exile are described in the apocalyptic Book of Daniel: "he was driven from men, and did eat grass as oxen, and his body was wet with the dew of heaven, till his hairs were grown like eagles' feathers, and his nails like birds' claws" (4:33). Beneath him is grassy ground and, as much a caption to the design as a final line of text, is a Blakean proverb: "One Law for the Lion & Ox is Oppression" (line 12).

component.illusobjdesc: A muscular nude male with long hair and beard, looking out at the viewer with his mouth open in an expression of apprehension and dismay, crawls leftward on hands and knees against a background that suggests gigantic tree trunks on the floor of a dark forest. The points of a crown can be seen on his head. This is apparently Nebuchadnezzar (not mentioned in the text), king of Babylon, enslaver of the Israelites, whose fall and exile are described in the apocalyptic Book of Daniel: "he was driven from men, and did eat grass as oxen, and his body was wet with the dew of heaven, till his hairs were grown like eagles' feathers, and his nails like birds' claws" (4:33).
The points of a crown can be seen on the figure's head.
The green coloring on the ground beneath the figure indicates grass.
A muscular nude male crawls leftward on hands and knees against a background that suggests gigantic tree trunks on the floor of a forest.
Beneath the male figure, as much a caption to the design as a final line of text, is a Blakean proverb: "One Law for the Lion & Ox is Oppression" (line 12).

lg.l: "One Law for the Lion & Ox is Oppression."

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the top of the plate, following "rules" in line 2, a hunched-over figure sits with its head resting on its knees at one end of a serpentine vegetative motif. Completing the vignette is another figure striding along the wavy ascender of "the" in line 3. Its position and gestures are ambiguous: the figure possibly faces right, a scarf floating behind it. Alternatively, one might view the figure as facing left, grasping a disproportionally large scrolled shape; the design would then perhaps illustrate the angel of lines 3 and 4 "embracing the flame of fire." Next to "Elijah" at the end of line 5, a gowned figure hovers, facing left (not clearly printed in this copy). A winged figure, also poorly printed in this copy, seen from behind hovers in the left margin between lines 5 and 6; vine-like forms appear to the right. A serried scene of five sundry figures—flanked by books on the right and more books, or possibly vegetation, on the left—also appears between the text of lines 5 and 6. Each of the figures sits or kneels. To the left of the first figure is an uncertain shape: possibly the profile of a horse or another figure. A small horse (minimally printed in this copy) leaps right above "world" in line 9. Following "well" at the end of the same line, a figure runs rightward, reaching for a vertical object which is more clearly a small child in other copies. The top half of the plate is dense with interlinear loops, vines, banners, and leaves, e.g., the vines and/or roots on either side of the figures populating the space between lines 5 and 6; the looped vines growing from the descender of "my" and the ascender of "friend," both in line 7; the elaborate curlicues following the text of line 11; and the small branch with spiky leaves extending from the "l" of "also" in line 10. Wing-like vegetable objects and/or soaring birds grace the plate— above "have" and "whether" in lines 9 and 11 respectively, for example.

component.illusobjdesc: At the top of the plate, following "rules" in line 2, a hunched-over figure sits with its head resting on its knees at one end of a serpentine vegetative motif. The figure faces left.
At the top of the plate, following "rules" in line 2, a hunched-over figure sits with its head resting on its knees at one end of a serpentine vegetative motif.

Completing the vignette next to "rules" in line 2 is a second figure striding along the wavy ascender of "the" in line 3. The figure seems to face left, holding a relatively large scrolled shape; a small protrusion on its back resembles wings. The design may illustrate the angel of lines 3 and 4 "embracing the flame of fire." Alternatively, one might view the figure as facing right, a scarf floating behind it. From this perspective, the figure's arms are extended.

A vine-, flame-, or even wave-like motif grows from the ascender of "the" in line 3, providing a surface on which a figure strides. At one end of the serpentine line, a small bud or flower is barely discernible near the upper right corner of the plate.
Following the text of line 5, a gowned(?) and somewhat shadowy figure hovers, facing left. Its arms are extended. The figure may represent the angel who "arose as Elijah" (line 5).
A nude, winged figure seen from behind hovers in the left margin between lines 5 and 6. The figure is more clearly printed in other copies.
Two vine-like forms appear right of the winged figure hovering in the left margin between lines 5 and 6.

An ambiguous scene of five(?) sundry figures—flanked by books on the right and more books, or possibly vegetation, on the left— appears between the text of lines 5 and 6. Each of the figures sits or kneels.
The first figure between lines 5 and 6 sits facing forward, possibly cross-legged, on the ground.

The second figure from the left between lines 5 and 6 kneels on one leg, its body hunched over. It faces right and down, as though looking at some indeterminate object held by the third figure sitting on the right, who faces forward. Perhaps the two are absorbed in a book, illustrating the angel and devil of lines 6-8 who read the Bible together.

The fourth figure from the left between lines 5 and 6 sits on the ground and faces left and down in a hunched-over posture. The fifth figure kneels behind its companion, resting its head on the other's back. It faces left, although the figure's head may be turned toward the viewer.
Preceding the first figure in the vignette between lines 5 and 6 is an uncertain shape: possibly the profile of a horse or other mammal facing left, its foreleg raised.
Preceding the first figure in the vignette between lines 5 and 6 is an indeterminate shape, possibly another seated figure facing left.

Following the final figure in the vignette between lines 5 and 6 are three or four books, two of which are stacked. The other two lean against them. More volumes(?) appear to the left of the group of figures.
Bracketing on the left the group of figures between lines 5 and 6 are either books—complementing the four volumes on the other side of the vignette—or else an indeterminate vegetable motif.

Roots and/or vines flank the group of figures in the vignette between lines 5 and 6. Climbing down the right margin, the vine becomes serpentine. A single-looped detachment from the vine motif appears in front of and below the hovering figure at the end of line 4.
Following "well" at the end of line 9, a figure runs rightward with arms extended horizontally, as though reaching for the vertical form (a child?) standing in front of it.

Following "well" at the end of line 9, a figure runs rightward with arms extended, as though reaching for the vertical form standing in front of it. In other copies, this vertical form is more clearly a small child, facing left.
Stylized leaves and/or vines ensconce the figure and child following "well" at the end of line 9. One leg of the figure on the left emerges from this foliage.
Above "world" in line 9, on the left side of the plate, a small horse (minimally printed in this copy) leaps or runs right.
Soaring birds and/or wing-like vegetable forms grace the plate—above "sense," "have," and "whether" in lines 8, 9, and 11 respectively, for example.

The top half of the plate is dense with interlinear loops, vines, banners, and leaves, e.g., the looped vines growing from the descender of "my" and the ascender of "friend," both in line 7; the snake-like flourish above "diabolical" in line 8; the elaborate, serpentine curlicues following the text of line 11; and the small branch with spiky leaves extending from the "l" of "also" in line 10. Wing-like vegetable forms and/or soaring birds grace the plate—above "sense" "have" and "whether" in lines 8, 9, and 11 respectively, for example.

lg.l: -pulse. not from rules.
When he had so spoken: I beheld the Angel who
stretched out his arms embracing the flame of fire
& he was consumed and arose as Elijah.
Note. This Angel, who is now become a Devil, is
my particular friend: we often read the Bible to-
-gether in its infernal or diabolical sense which
the world shall have if they behave well.
I have also; The Bible of Hell: which the world
shall have whether they will or no.
One Law for the Lion & Ox is Oppression

illustration.illusobjdesc: Blue, yellow, and rose washes suggest sky at sunrise or sunset. Looped vines grow from the descenders of "Song" and "Liberty" in the plate's second line. The first of these vegetative motifs joins with the "E" of "Eternal" in line 3. To the right of "A Song of Liberty," a stylized leaf appears. Three grape leaves on a branch follow "Earth" in line 4. Two lines down, a long, thin branch with abundant tiny leaves stretches to the right margin. More grape leaves—these attached to a vine with a two-looped tendril—ornament the space next to "Rome" in line 11. Two soaring birds fly left of the vine. A flame-like leaf, for which a gowned female reaches, extends from the "g" of "howling" in line 16. More vegetation appears behind the figure, as well as near the right margin of line 19. A leaf-bearing vine grows from the descender of "deep" in line 22. Adjacent to it are three birds—the two outside ones are small and nondescript—followed by some seemingly wind-blown vegetation—or perhaps the feathery objects represent the "jealous wings [that] wav'd / over the deep," mentioned in lines 21 and 22. In the bottom left corner of the plate, the ubiquitous grapevine and leaf combination continues, attached to the "y" of "jealousy." The "g's" of "among" and "flaming" in line 25 also sport flourishes, the former vegetative, the latter a tassel, possibly representing the "flaming hair" named in the text. Various other small- scale vegetative designs adorn the plate, e.g., the leaf-bearing stem preceding verse 7 in line 15, and the leafy attachment to the "A" in line 2.

component.illusobjdesc: Blue, yellow, and rose washes suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

Numerous vines and grape leaves ornament the plate: in line 2, a vine connects the "g" of "Song" with the "E" of "Eternal" in line 3, and a five-looped vine, suggestive of a spiral, extends from the "y" of "Liberty" (line 2). Three grape leaves follow "Earth" in line 4. Further down, right of line 11, four grape leaves grow from a long tendril that stretches to the right margin. A leaf-bearing vine is attached to the "p" of "deep" in line 22. At the bottom left corner of the plate, the vine and grape leaf emblem extends from the "y" of "jealousy" (line 25).

Various other vegetative motifs adorn the plate: to the right of line 2, "A Song of Liberty," a stylized leaf appears against a blue wash of sky. Attached to the "t" of "faint" in line 6, a long, thin branch with abundant tiny leaves stretches to the right margin. A leaf-bearing stem grows from the "g" of "among" in line 25. Smaller-scale motifs appear passim, e.g., the leafy flourishes of "wav'd" at the end of line 21 and of "A" in line 2, and the detached branch with leaves preceding verse 7 in line 15.
Five birds grace the plate: two soar to the right of "Rome" in line 11, and three—the outside ones small and nondescript— fly above "burned aloft" in line 23.

A flame-like leaf, for which a gowned female reaches, extends from the "g" of "howling" in line 16. More flame- or wing-like vegetation appears behind the figure, as well as near the right margin of line 19. The three soaring birds of line 22 are followed by some seemingly wind-blown leaves, or perhaps the feathery fragments represent the "jealous wings [that] wav'd/over the deep," mentioned in lines 21 and 22.
Following "howling" in line 17, a hovering female faces left. She wears a gown and extends one arm, touching the flame-like leaf in front of her. Her body is horizontal.
At the bottom of the plate, a flame-like(?) tassel grows from the "g" of "flaming" in line 25. The motif may visually represent the "flaming hair" of the text (line 25).

lg.l: 1. The Eternal Female groand! it was
heard over all the Earth:
2. Albions coast is sick silent; the A-
-merican meadows faint!
3 Shadows of Prophecy shiver along by
the lakes and the rivers and mutter across
the ocean, France rend down thy dungeon;
4. Golden Spain burst the barriers of old
Rome;
5. Cast thy keys O Rome into the deep
down falling, even to eternity down falling,

6. And weep Five words were deleted from the copper plate at line 14, following "weep": "and bow they reverend locks!" They are absent in all copies excepts L and M, which consist of Plates 25-27 only, with Plate 25 in its first state.
7. In her trembling hands she took the
new born terror howling;
8. On those infinite mountains of light
now barr'd out by the atlantic sea, the new
born fire stood before the starry king!
9. Flag'd with grey brow'd snows and thun-
-derous visages the jealous wings wav'd
over the deep.
10. The speary hand burned aloft, unbuck-
-led was the shield, forth went the hand
of jealousy among the flaming hair. and

illustration.illusobjdesc: Blue, yellow, and rose tinting throughout the plate suggests a sky at sunrise or sunset. Following "night" in line 3, a stag leaps right, a mirror image of the interlinear stag on Plate 8. Just beyond it, a leafless tree arches to the ground. An upside-down figure personifies the "falling" fire of line 4. Next to it are some hatched lines wherein are discernible two horses running left in other copies, but here the cluster of lines (if representational at all) suggests vegetation because of the green tinting. Two figures, many of the details of their gestures and positions indistinct, follow "forehead" in line 9. They sit facing each other, the second gowned or otherwise draped. To the right of these figures, another tree(?) arches right, its leafless branch seemingly pointing toward a serpentine vine that connects with the "h" of "shot" at the end of line 10. Further down, a snake (or simply a line?) extends from "away" in line 13 to the right margin. A relatively large-scale interlinear branch and leaf combination ornaments the space beside "rocks" in line 19. Hovering above "then" in line 22, a somewhat shadowy figure faces right, its body horizontal. It extends one arm forward, touching the hand of a sitting figure. A group of five figures, possibly signifying the "gloomy king" and his retinue of lines 16-18, appears after "king" in line 24: the first figure stands facing right; the second sits cross-legged(?) on the ground. They are followed by two figures who stand with arms extended, hailing the final figure, perhaps the king. He walks toward them with arms outstretched. Above "his" at the end of line 25 is a vivid leaf. Various other vegetative motifs adorn the plate, e.g., the looped vines growing from the ascenders of "London" and "thunder" in lines 5 and 25; the leaf extending from the "h" of "then" in line 22; and the banner waving from the "b" of "born" in line 2.

component.illusobjdesc: Blue, yellow, and rose tinting throughout the plate suggests a sky at sunrise or sunset.
Following "night" in line 3, a stag—its horns discernible—leaps right, a mirror image of the interlinear stag on Plate 8.
Just beyond the stag following "night" in line 3, a tree arches right, its leafless branches nearly touching the ground.

To the right of the leafless tree below line 2, an upside- down figure personifies the "falling" fire of line 4. The figure is seen from behind and faces down. Its arms are raised at 135 degrees. Fire or flame-like drapery trails behind the figure's legs.
Fire or flame-like drapery trails behind the falling figure's legs.

Discernible in the hatching near the right margin at the ends of lines 3 and 4 are two horses leaping or running right in other copies, but here the cluster of lines (if representational at all) suggests some sort of vegetation because of the green tinting.
A sketchy scene follows the word "forehead" in line 9: the first of two figures sits facing right, its arms slightly extended. The figure appears engrossed in some indeterminable activity.
Following the word "forehead" in line 9, the second of two figures sits facing left, its legs extended. The figure is robed or wrapped in a blanket.

An ambiguous motif appears below "winged" in line 8 and to the right of a seated pair of figures. It may be a tree or stump, not unlike the larger tree of line 3, with a leafless branch extending toward or pointing at a serpentine vine.

At the end of line 9 is a tree or stump whose leafless branch seems to point toward a serpentine vine near the right margin of the plate. This vine is attached to the ascender of "h" in the word below (line 10).
Following "away" in line 13, a snake (or simply a line?) extends to the right margin.
A leaf-bearing stem or branch follows "rocks" in line 19 and stretches to the right margin of the plate.
Hovering above "then" in line 22, a shadowy figure faces right, its body horizontal. It extends one arm forward, touching the hand of a seated figure.
Following "then" in line 22, a figure sits facing forward, but with its head possibly turned to the left. It has one arm raised horizontally and touches the hand of the hovering figure above left.

Toward the bottom of the plate, a group of figures—five in all—appears above verse 18 of the "Song" (Plate 25, line 2). They may illustrate the "gloomy king" (far right) and his retinue, described in lines 15- 24.

Following "king" in line 24 is a group of five figures, perhaps the monarch and his retinue, described in lines 15-24. The first pair possibly represents two of the king's "councellors," "warriors," or "veterans," cited in lines 15-16. One of the figures stands facing right, arms slightly extended. The second sits cross- legged(?) on the ground. The first figure is gowned.

The second pair of figures following "king" in line 24 possibly represents two of the king's "councellors," "warriors," or "veterans," cited in lines 15-16. They stand facing right. The more distant of the two extends one arm forward. Its companion seems to hold an object; its arms may also be outstretched. Both figures are gowned.

The last figure of line 24 may illustrate the "gloomy king" of the text. He appears to wear a gown that trails behind him; he walks leftward toward his "counsellors" and "warriors" (lines 15-16). The king's arms are extended horizontally.
A vivid leaf appears above "his" at the end of line 25.

Various vegetative motifs adorn the plate, e.g., the looped vines growing from the ascenders of "London" and "thunder" in lines 5 and 25; the leaf extending from the "h" of "then" in line 22; and the banner waving from the "b" of "born" in line 2.

lg.l: hurl'd the new born wonder thro' the starry
night.
11. The fire, the fire, is falling!
12. Look up! look up! O citizen of London
enlarge thy countenance; O Jew, leave coun
ting gold! return to thy oil and wine; O
African! black African! (go. winged thought
widen his forehead.)
13. The fiery limbs, the flaming hair, shot
like the sinking sun into the western sea.
14. Wak'd from his eternal sleep, the hoary
element roaring fled away;
15. Down rushd beating his wings in vain
the jealous king; his grey brow'd councel-
-lors, thunderous warriors, curl'd veterans.
among helms, and shields, and chariots
horses, elephants: banners, castles, slings
and rocks,
16. Falling, rushing, ruining! buried in
the ruins, on Urthona's dens.
17. All night beneath the ruins, then
their sullen flames faded emerge round
the gloomy king,
18. With thunder and fire: leading his
starry hosts thro' the waste wilderness

illustration.illusobjdesc: Thin blue washes suggest sky right and left of "Chorus" (line 14) and in the right and left bottom corners. Following "dismay" in line 4, a figure holds a staff—or a scepter if one takes him for the "starry" (Plate 25, line 19) and "gloomy" (Plate 26, line 24) king of this "Song of Liberty" (Plate 25, line 2). He kneels on one leg and points(?) toward another figure with his left arm, raised horizontally. Running amidst wispy clouds, this second figure may represent the "son of fire in his eastern / cloud," who is named in lines 5 and 6 and in whose direction the king of the text casts his eyes. Three lines down (line 9), two horses, one of which is mounted, gallop leftward in the direction of another horse(?)—this one recumbent—and an indistinct form, both of which rest on some grassy tableland. The horse motif reappears midway down the design, where two horses flank the inscription "Chorus" in line 14. The horse on the left gallops or leaps toward the text. Its companion rears up on hind legs, arching its head and back. A small bird soars to the right of and above "Chorus," which is circumscribed by vegetative flourishes, including wavy, serpentine lines. Above line 22, a flock of birds—the largest an eagle with head held high—soars on extended wings. Various other vegetative motifs adorn the plate, e.g., the looped vines growing from the "t" of "breast" and the "d" of "accepted" in lines 7 and 17, respectively; a small leaf- bearing branch below "Spurning" in line 8; and the vegetable ribbon extending from the descender of "Holy" in line 22.

component.illusobjdesc: Thin blue washes suggest sky right and left of "Chorus" (line 14) and in the right and left bottom corners.

Following "dismay" in line 4, a figure holds a staff—or a scepter if one takes him for the king of the "Song" who, in lines 3-5, casts "his beamy eyelids" in the direction of the "son of fire," visually depicted near the right margin. The king(?) kneels on one leg and points or otherwise gestures toward this second figure.

Following "dismay" in line 4, a figure kneels on one leg, holding a staff or scepter. To his right is another figure. Leaping or running amidst wispy clouds, this second figure may represent the "son of fire in his eastern / cloud," who is named in lines 5 and 6. His arms are raised nearly horizontally.

The second figure following "dismay" in line 4 is surrounded by wispy, curving lines, suggestive of clouds; the visual details reinforce the epithet of lines 5 and 6: "the son of fire in his eastern / cloud."
Following "breast" in line 7, a horse and an indistinct form—perhaps vegetation—lie resting on a bit of grassy tableland. The horse faces right.
Two horses—the first of which carries a rider—gallop leftward in the direction of the recumbent horse following "breast" in line 7.
A rider sits astride the first horse following "breast" in line 7.
A clump of indeterminate vegetation, possibly tall grass, grows between the end of line 7 and the recumbent horse.
Two horses flank the inscription "Chorus" in line 14. The horse on the left gallops or leaps toward the text.
Two horses flank the inscription "Chorus" in line 14. The horse on the right rears up on its hind legs, bending its head back. It faces left and up.

The plate's inscription, "Chorus," in line 14 is circumscribed by vegetative flourishes, including wavy, serpentine lines above and below it. Leaves emerge, fan-like, from a stem curving around the inscription. A slender vine is intertwined with the larger one below the word.
A small bird flies to the right of and above "Chorus" in line 14. Over line 22, a flock of birds—the largest an eagle with head held high—soars on extended wings. The eagle is seen from behind.

Above "letchery call" in line 20 is a serpentine banner. Various other vegetative motifs adorn the plate, e.g., the looped vines growing from the "t" of "breast" and the "d" of "accepted" in lines 7 and 17, respectively; a small leaf-bearing branch below "Spurning" in line 8; a single detached leaf above "curses" in line 9; and the vegetable ribbon extending from the descender of "Holy" in line 22.
